Gold: The shiny metal is taking a breather today, softening slightly after a massive 19% run-up recently. It remains a favorite safety blanket for investors nervous about the tech sector. Foreign Markets: It’s quiet in Asia with many markets closed for the Lunar New Year. Across the pond, European indices are catching the American cold, with their own tech stocks dipping on similar AI concerns. The American Indexes Dow Jones: Trending slightly down to mixed. The blue chips are saving face thanks to defensive stocks. S&P 500: Modestly lower. The rotation out of tech is heavy, but strength in utilities and staples is keeping the floor from falling out. Nasdaq: The biggest loser today. The tech-heavy index is bearing the brunt of the "sell first, ask questions later" attitude toward AI names. Winners & Losers 📉 Loser: General Mills (-7.2%) The maker of Cheerios is leaving a sour taste today. They cut their profit forecast, citing customers who are "feeling less confident." It’s a sign that inflation fatigue is real at the grocery store level. 📈 Winner: Warner Bros. Discovery (+2.3%) Who doesn't love a bidding war? The stock popped on reports that it's seeking a "best and final" offer from Paramount, which is trying to outbid Netflix. Content is king, at least for today. 📉 Loser: Genuine Parts (-11.9%) The company behind NAPA Auto Parts is sputtering. After reporting weak results and announcing a complex plan to split into two companies, investors headed for the exit. 📉 Loser: Big Tech (Alphabet, Nvidia, Microsoft) No single piece of bad news hit these giants, but the mood has shifted. Investors are cashing out their massive AI gains and moving money into safer, boring corners of the market—like electric utilities and toothpaste manufacturers.

title: The AI That Hires Itself: Anthropic's Quantum Leap
description:
If you use a computer for work or a smartphone for, well, anything, your digital life just got a massive boost this morning. San Francisco-based Anthropic has officially pulled the curtain back on Claude Sonnet 4.6. While the name sounds technical, it means the free version of AI just became nearly as smart as the expensive, professional-grade versions used by engineers.

This release, hitting screens today, February 17, is part of a 1-2 punch from the company. Just twelve days ago, they launched 'Opus 4.6,' a heavyweight model designed for massive corporations and complex scientific research. Think of Opus as a high-end luxury semi-truck built to haul freight across the country. Today’s Sonnet 4.6 is the sleek, updated sedan—it’s faster, it’s now the default for everyone on the free plan, and it has inherited the high-end engine from its bigger brother.

So, what does this actually look like in your browser? The most significant change is what experts call 'Computer Use.' For the first time, this AI doesn’t just answer questions; it can actually navigate a computer like a human would. If you are a local small business owner trying to fill out state forms or a student researching a complex project, Sonnet 4.6 can now jump between browser tabs, fill out web forms, and organize spreadsheets autonomously. It has graduated from being a 'calculator for words' to a digital assistant that can actually click buttons and move files.

Another breakthrough is its 'memory.' Most AI systems begin to forget the start of a conversation once it gets too long—a problem called 'context rot.' Sonnet 4.6 arrives with a '1-million-token window.' To translate that into plain English: you could feed it 2,500 pages of text (roughly the length of ten thick novels) and it can remember and reason across every single page simultaneously. Whether it’s a stack of legal contracts or a year’s worth of medical records, this AI can 'read' the whole pile in seconds without losing the thread.

Why is this different from the Opus model released earlier this month? While Opus 4.6 is the undisputed king of complex reasoning—even 'hiring' smaller versions of itself to work on parallel tasks—it can be slow and expensive. Today's Sonnet 4.6 is designed for speed. It brings those high-end reasoning skills into the tools we use for daily chores, like drafting emails or organizing a family vacation, without the wait or the price tag.

As these tools become more capable of acting on our behalf, safety remains the conversation in Dayton’s tech circles. Researchers found that this new generation of AI is much better at following instructions, but it’s also much more autonomous. For now, the takeaway for the average user is simple: the assistant in your pocket just got a lot more helpful, and it’s now capable of doing the 'busy work' that used to take us all afternoon.

title: Strait Talk: Iran Shutters Key Waterway Mid-Negotiation
description:
GENEVA — Tensions in the Persian Gulf reached a fever pitch on Tuesday as Iran announced a sudden, temporary closure of the Strait of Hormuz. The move, characterized by Tehran as a safety measure for live-fire naval drills, coincided precisely with a critical second round of indirect nuclear negotiations between Iranian and American officials in Switzerland.

The Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) declared the strategic choke point—conduit for nearly a fifth of the world’s oil supply—off-limits to commercial traffic for a six-hour window. While the closure was partial and temporary, the message was unambiguous: Iran retains the capability to disrupt global energy markets at will. Oil prices reacted immediately, with Brent crude spiking on fears of a prolonged blockade before stabilizing as the waterway reopened.

Meanwhile, thousands of miles away in Geneva, the atmosphere was equally charged. Delegations led by Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi and U.S. envoys representing the Trump administration, including Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, engaged in proximity talks mediated by Omani officials. The discussions aim to resurrect a framework for nuclear containment in exchange for sanctions relief, a prospect that has remained elusive amidst escalating rhetoric.

The diplomatic gamble is high. Just hours prior to the drills, Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei issued a stern warning regarding U.S. naval assets in the region, asserting that American warships remain vulnerable to Iranian missilery. Despite the saber-rattling, insiders describe the Geneva sessions as 'constructive,' with preliminary agreements reached on guiding principles for future inspections. However, the juxtaposition of ballistic drills and diplomatic overtures underscores Tehran’s 'fight and talk' strategy—leveraging military volatility to strengthen its hand at the negotiating table.

title: The Silver Fox Stops the Clock: Why Anderson Cooper is Leaving 60 Minutes
description:
After two decades of juggling two of the most demanding jobs in broadcast journalism, Anderson Cooper is finally choosing sides. The veteran correspondent announced he will depart '60 Minutes' at the end of the current season in May 2026, marking the end of an era for the CBS powerhouse.

On the surface, Cooper’s exit is a classic case of 'family first.' In a heartfelt statement, the 58-year-old newsman cited a desire to spend more time with his young sons, Wyatt and Sebastian. For 20 years, Cooper has been the ultimate frequent flyer, balancing his nightly CNN anchor duties with the rigorous global travel required by the legendary newsmagazine. At some point, the ticking clock in the background starts to feel like a countdown of missed bedtimes.

However, industry insiders suggest the timing isn't just about domestic bliss. Cooper’s departure coincides with a period of unprecedented turbulence at CBS News. Following the Paramount-Skydance merger, the newsroom has been under the firm, often polarizing leadership of Editor-in-Chief Bari Weiss. The shift has sparked internal friction, most notably following the network's recent $16 million settlement with Donald Trump over a disputed 2024 interview with Kamala Harris. 

Reports of spiked segments and a shifting editorial North Star have left several '60 Minutes' veterans feeling disillusioned. While Cooper has remained diplomatic, his exit allows him to retreat to the familiar territory of CNN, where he recently inked a massive contract extension. At CNN, he will continue to helm 'Anderson Cooper 360°' and his prestige Sunday series, 'The Whole Story.'

For '60 Minutes,' the loss is immense. Cooper brought a certain 'cool factor' and a younger demographic to a broadcast that often skews older. As the silver fox packs his bags, the program is left to navigate a leadership identity crisis and the daunting task of finding a successor who carries the same gravitas. For now, the clock keeps ticking, but it will sound a little quieter without Cooper in the lineup.

title: Raiders Flip the Script: Michigan Sweep Sparks February Surge
description:
If the Wright State women’s basketball team was looking for a sign that the tides have turned, they found it in The Mitten. After a grueling mid-winter stretch that saw the Raiders drop seven consecutive contests, Coach Kari Hoffman’s squad has rediscovered its grit, winning three of its last five games and riding a two-game winning streak back to the Nutter Center.

The turnaround began on February 5 with a gutsy 70-67 win over Purdue Fort Wayne, finally snapping the month-long skid. While the Raiders suffered a setback two days later in a 73-63 loss to IUPUI on February 7, they didn't let the momentum die there. Instead, they hit the road and executed their first 'Michigan Sweep' since the 2019-20 season.

The road trip was a clinic in adjustment and defensive intensity. First, the Raiders dismantled Detroit Mercy 78-61 on February 12, led by a balanced offensive attack. But it was the Valentine’s Day showdown at Oakland that truly showcased the team's potential. Wright State locked down the Golden Grizzlies, allowing just 44 points—the lowest total for a Division I opponent in the Hoffman era—in a commanding 62-44 victory.

Senior guard Breezie Williams has been the engine of this resurgence, averaging 13.0 points per game and proving instrumental in closing out tight possessions. Beside her, Claire Henson has provided the stability, leading the team on the glass (6.3 rpg) and anchoring the defensive improvements that were on full display in Rochester.

Now, the Raiders (9-18, 5-11 Horizon) return to Fairborn tonight for the annual 'Pink Game' against Milwaukee. It’s a matchup with instant stakes: not only is it a chance to extend their winning streak to three, but it’s also an opportunity for revenge. The Panthers handed Wright State a stinging 75-70 loss back on January 31—the final defeat of that seven-game slide. With the Horizon League tournament on the horizon, the Raiders are proving they may have saved their best basketball for when it matters most.

title: Measles at the Doorstep: Why Dayton Must Stay Alert
description:
By mid-February 2026, the United States has already recorded over 910 confirmed cases of measles—nearly 40% of last year's total in just six weeks. While the epicenter of this surge is currently South Carolina, which accounts for nearly 70% of national cases, the virus has officially crossed state lines into Ohio. Three confirmed cases have been reported in Cuyahoga County, linked to interstate travel.

For residents of the Miami Valley, the most critical number right now is zero: there are currently zero active cases or exposure sites in Dayton or Montgomery County. However, local health officials warn that this statistic is fragile. Public Health – Dayton & Montgomery County has issued alerts to local physicians to heighten vigilance, mindful of the 2024 outbreak at Dayton Children’s that exposed hundreds. The virus is exceptionally contagious, capable of lingering in the air for two hours after an infected person leaves a room, making 'exposure' a silent and often invisible event.

The drivers of this 'perfect storm' are threefold: declining vaccination rates, increased international travel, and widespread misinformation. Herd immunity requires a 95% vaccination rate; national kindergarten coverage has slipped to roughly 92.5%. This gap allows the virus to find pockets of vulnerability, causing outbreaks that spread like wildfire. Beyond the immediate fever and rash, the virus poses a sinister long-term threat known as 'immune amnesia,' where the infection effectively erases the immune system's memory of other diseases, leaving victims susceptible to common infections for months or years.

While panic is unnecessary, preparation is non-negotiable. If you were born after 1957, confirm you have received two doses of the MMR vaccine, which is 97% effective for life. If records are unavailable, a simple blood titer test can confirm immunity. For those needing vaccination, the Public Health clinic at the Reibold Building on Main Street remains our best frontline defense. We are not in a crisis yet, but the fire is burning just a few counties away.

title: Union City Scandal: School Secretary Jailed on 5 Counts of Child Seduction
description:
A major scandal has erupted on the Darke County border involving a Union City High School secretary accused of illicit relationships with students. Alicia Hughes, 31, is currently held in the Randolph County Jail on a $25,000 cash-only bond, charged with five felony counts of Child Seduction.

The investigation began this past weekend under volatile circumstances. Union City Police were dispatched to a residence regarding a battery report. Upon arrival, officers learned that Hughes' husband had allegedly confronted her after discovering her with an 18-year-old student, leading to a physical altercation. However, the subsequent police probe uncovered a darker layer to the story: evidence of a separate, ongoing sexual relationship between Hughes and a different student, a 17-year-old minor.

According to court documents, investigators determined that Hughes engaged in sexual intercourse with the 17-year-old on at least five separate occasions. The revelations prompted immediate action from the Randolph Eastern School Corporation. Superintendent Neal Adams issued a statement confirming that Hughes has been removed from all school duties and that the district is cooperating fully with law enforcement.

While the high school is located just across the state line in Indiana, the Union City community is deeply integrated with Darke County, Ohio, sending shockwaves through families on both sides of the border. Hughes remains in custody awaiting her initial court appearance.

title: Jesse Jackson, Civil Rights Titan and Political Pioneer, Dies at 84
description:
Reverend Jesse Jackson, the fiery orator and protégé of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. who twice sought the presidency and spent six decades redefining the American political landscape, died Tuesday at the age of 84. His family confirmed he passed peacefully in Chicago, marking the end of a long battle with Parkinson’s disease and Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP).

Jackson’s departure leaves a massive void in the civil rights movement. From the balcony of the Lorraine Motel in 1968 to the podiums of the Democratic National Convention, Jackson served as the bridge between the nonviolent protests of the 1960s and the modern era of Black political power. His 1984 and 1988 presidential campaigns were not merely symbolic; they registered millions of new voters and proved that a Black man could be a formidable contender for the nation’s highest office, effectively clearing the path for Barack Obama twenty years later.

In his final years, Jackson’s once-booming voice was silenced by PSP, a rare neurological disorder. Yet, his presence remained a constant at marches and vigils. Known for his 'Rainbow Coalition'—a philosophy of inclusion for the marginalized across all races—Jackson’s legacy is defined by his ability to organize. Whether negotiating the release of American hostages abroad or challenging corporate America to diversify its boardrooms via his Rainbow PUSH Coalition, he was a master of leveraging moral authority into political results.

Tributes have poured in from across the political spectrum, with leaders describing him as a 'force of nature' who taught a generation to 'Keep Hope Alive.' He is survived by his wife, Jacqueline, and their five children. Funeral arrangements are expected to be announced later this week, with a national memorial likely to draw dignitaries from around the globe.

title: Atoms Over Bits: The Great 2026 Market Re-Wiring
description:
For nearly a decade, the recipe for wealth was simple: buy anything that ended in '.ai' or '.com' and wait for the cloud to rain gold. But as we move through February 2026, the 'Software-mageddon' we feared last year has matured into a violent, seemingly permanent rotation into the tangible.

Investors are no longer mesmerized by the promise of infinite scaling. Instead, they are chasing the 'Atoms over Bits' trade. The catalysts are twofold: the 'DeepSeek shock' of 2025, which commoditized high-end AI models, and the full implementation of the One Big Beautiful Bill (OBBBA) Act this January. The latter has turned domestic industrial heartlands like Ohio into the new growth engines, offering tax deductions for 'heavy' assets that make the thin margins of SaaS look like a liability.

Energy and Industrials are the new market darlings. With the OBBBA Act’s aggressive incentives for domestic fossil fuel production and midstream infrastructure deregulation, the 'Old Economy' is enjoying a valuation premium we haven't seen in thirty years. While tech giants grapple with the 'Liberation Day' tariff legacy and its disruption of global silicon supply chains, the Russell 2000 is staging a historic breakout. Small-cap domestic manufacturers are suddenly the 'safest' bet in a world that values resilience over global reach.

The divergence is most visible in the indices. While the cap-weighted S&P 500 stumbles under the weight of its tech concentration, the Equal-Weight S&P 500 (RSP) is hitting fresh all-time highs. This isn't a market crash; it’s a market correction of priorities. We are witnessing the re-industrialization of the American portfolio. For the Dayton investor, the takeaway is clear: the most valuable thing in the room is no longer the code—it's the turbine, the pipe, and the power plant.

title: Berkshire Takes a Bigger Slice of Domino’s
description:
Berkshire Hathaway has quietly deepened its bet on Domino’s Pizza, reinforcing a position that has grown steadily since the conglomerate first disclosed a stake in 2024.

According to its latest SEC 13F filing for the quarter ended December 31, 2025, Berkshire increased its holdings in Domino’s by roughly 12 to 13 percent, bringing its total ownership to more than 3.3 million shares. The move places Berkshire among the pizza chain’s largest institutional investors, with an ownership stake estimated in the high single digits.

The increase is notable not because it signals a takeover — it does not — but because it underscores sustained conviction. Berkshire has added to the position across multiple quarters rather than making a one-time allocation. In a portfolio as large and closely watched as Berkshire’s, repeated buying carries weight.

The Domino’s investment also comes during a period of portfolio recalibration inside Berkshire. The conglomerate has trimmed certain legacy holdings in recent quarters while selectively expanding others, including positions in energy, insurance and media. Adding to Domino’s suggests confidence in a consumer-facing business that generates steady cash flow and maintains a globally recognized brand.

Domino’s has long been considered one of the restaurant industry’s most disciplined operators. Its heavily franchised model limits capital intensity while producing consistent royalty streams. The company has historically paired international expansion with aggressive share repurchases, magnifying per-share earnings growth over time. That combination — brand strength, franchise economics and shareholder-friendly capital allocation — fits neatly within Berkshire’s traditional preference for durable businesses with predictable returns.

While Warren Buffett remains chairman, Berkshire’s day-to-day investment decisions increasingly reflect the influence of senior portfolio managers and the company’s broader leadership bench. Whether the Domino’s position originated directly from Buffett or from one of Berkshire’s investment lieutenants, the repeated additions suggest long-term orientation rather than short-term trading.

For investors, the signal is less about pizza and more about discipline. Domino’s operates in a competitive and inflation-sensitive sector, yet its scale, digital ordering infrastructure and global footprint have helped it defend margins even in choppy consumer environments. Berkshire’s growing stake indicates belief that those structural advantages remain intact.

The position is still modest relative to Berkshire’s largest holdings, but its steady expansion makes it one of the more intriguing developments in the conglomerate’s recent filings. In a market often driven by momentum and speculation, Berkshire’s approach remains incremental and conviction-driven.

For Domino’s shareholders, the endorsement of one of the world’s most scrutinized investment firms adds a layer of credibility. For the broader market, it is a reminder that even in a diversified empire spanning insurance, railroads and energy, Berkshire still finds room at the table for a well-run consumer brand — and is willing to keep ordering more.

title: YouTube Goes Dark in Global Glitch
description:
For several hours Tuesday evening, the world’s largest video platform flickered offline.

Users across the United States and internationally reported widespread problems accessing YouTube, with outage tracking services logging a dramatic spike in complaints beginning shortly before 8 p.m. Eastern Time. At its peak, hundreds of thousands of users reported issues ranging from blank homepages to the now-familiar “Something went wrong” error message.

The disruption appeared to affect both desktop and mobile users. Core features such as subscription feeds, recommendations, and Shorts failed to load for many. Some users were able to access videos through direct links, suggesting the outage did not fully cripple YouTube’s video hosting infrastructure but instead impacted front-end systems, account services, or content delivery layers.

Reports quickly spread across social media platforms, where frustrated viewers and creators alike compared notes. For digital creators who rely on YouTube as a primary source of income, even a short-lived outage can translate into lost ad impressions and diminished real-time engagement. For viewers, the interruption underscored just how deeply embedded the platform has become in daily routines — from entertainment and education to live news consumption.

YouTube acknowledged the disruption publicly, confirming it was investigating elevated error rates and service failures. While the company did not provide a detailed technical explanation, service gradually began stabilizing later in the evening, and complaint volumes declined significantly within a few hours.

Though major global outages remain relatively rare for a platform of YouTube’s scale, they are not unprecedented. Modern content platforms depend on vast, distributed cloud infrastructure, complex routing systems, authentication services, and content delivery networks. A misconfiguration, software deployment error, or infrastructure failure in any one of those layers can cascade outward, creating symptoms that appear widespread even if the underlying fault is isolated.

The episode also serves as a reminder of the centralization of the modern internet. When a single platform experiences disruption, the ripple effects extend far beyond inconvenience. News organizations, independent creators, advertisers, educators, and livestreamers all depend on uninterrupted uptime.

By late evening, service appeared largely restored for most users. YouTube has not yet disclosed the precise cause of the outage, and it remains unclear whether a full post-incident report will be released.

For a few hours, however, the digital world was reminded that even the most dominant platforms are not immune to failure — and that when YouTube goes dark, the silence is felt everywhere.

title: Streaming War Reignites: Warner Reopens Paramount Talks
description:
The high-stakes battle for control of Warner Bros. Discovery has roared back to life.

Just weeks after Warner Bros. Discovery formally agreed to sell its studio and streaming assets to Netflix in a deal valued at roughly $72 billion, the company has reopened negotiations with Paramount Skydance following a rare seven-day waiver granted by Netflix. The temporary reprieve allows Warner to engage with Paramount about a potentially superior offer — a dramatic twist in what is already one of the largest and most consequential media acquisition fights in modern history.

Under the December agreement, Netflix secured the rights to acquire Warner’s studio and direct-to-consumer streaming business, including HBO and Max, in an all-cash transaction. Warner’s board unanimously recommended the deal at the time, citing certainty of value and the strength of Netflix’s global distribution platform. However, Paramount Skydance, backed by deep-pocketed investors and strategic ambitions of its own, has continued pressing a hostile bid aimed at purchasing the entire Warner Bros. Discovery company — not just its entertainment division.

That distinction is critical. Paramount’s proposal would fold in Warner’s broader television and cable networks, including CNN and Discovery’s portfolio of lifestyle brands, effectively reshaping the traditional and streaming media landscape in one stroke. While Netflix’s bid focuses on content and streaming scale, Paramount’s offer is positioned as a full corporate merger play.

Paramount initially offered approximately $30 per share in a transaction valued north of $100 billion including debt — higher on paper than Netflix’s deal. Since then, Paramount has sweetened its proposal, offering to cover Warner’s breakup fee owed to Netflix and reportedly signaling willingness to raise its per-share price further during the renewed negotiation window.

The waiver granted by Netflix does not nullify its agreement. Rather, it allows Warner to determine whether Paramount’s revised proposal qualifies as a "superior offer" under fiduciary standards. Netflix retains the right to match any competing bid should Warner’s board pivot.

For shareholders, the reopening of talks represents leverage. For regulators, it signals the possibility of two vastly different merger scenarios. A Netflix acquisition would consolidate a major Hollywood studio inside the world’s largest streaming platform, potentially intensifying antitrust scrutiny over market dominance in subscription video. A Paramount-Warner combination, meanwhile, would create a sprawling traditional-and-streaming hybrid giant with unmatched film libraries and cable news assets — a different but equally significant regulatory challenge.

Wall Street reacted swiftly to the news of resumed negotiations, with shares of both companies climbing on speculation of a bidding escalation. Investors appear to be betting that competitive tension could drive up the final purchase price before a scheduled shareholder vote next month.

Beyond the boardroom maneuvering lies a broader industry reality: legacy studios are scrambling for scale in an era where streaming economics remain volatile and debt loads are heavy. Content libraries, sports rights, news divisions, and international distribution pipelines are no longer just prestige assets — they are survival tools in a rapidly consolidating marketplace.

Whether Netflix ultimately prevails, Paramount lands a knockout bid, or the two suitors are forced into even more aggressive terms, one outcome is already clear: the streaming wars have entered a new and unpredictable phase. And at the center of it all stands Warner Bros. Discovery — once again the most coveted prize in Hollywood.

title: Montgomery Returns as Flyers Grind Past Davidson
description:
The Dayton Flyers reminded the Atlantic 10 on Saturday night that when they defend, rebound and share the ball, they are still one of the most dangerous teams in the league.

Dayton’s 70-59 victory over the Davidson Wildcats at UD Arena was not flashy, but it was authoritative. The Flyers controlled the glass from start to finish, dominated second-chance opportunities and never allowed Davidson’s perimeter rhythm to fully take hold. For a team that has battled inconsistency in conference play, it was a mature, workmanlike performance at exactly the right time.

The most encouraging development was the return of Deshayne Montgomery. After missing time due to illness, Montgomery came off the bench and delivered 13 efficient points, attacking gaps, finishing in transition and providing a steadying presence in half-court sets. His energy was noticeable. The ball moved better when he was on the floor, and Dayton’s spacing improved as Davidson was forced to respect his ability to score off the dribble.

Dayton built a first-half cushion and leaned on its rebounding edge to maintain control. The Flyers limited second chances on one end while creating them on the other, turning physicality into points. That advantage on the boards allowed Dayton to survive cold stretches from the perimeter and avoid the scoring droughts that have plagued them at times this season.

With the win, the Flyers moved to 16-9 overall and 7-5 in Atlantic 10 play, good for a tie for fourth in a tightly packed conference race. The standings remain fluid, and every possession from here on out carries postseason implications. Dayton has shown flashes of high-level play this year, but sustaining that intensity has been the challenge.

Saturday’s performance offered a blueprint. Defend without fouling. Own the glass. Let multiple players contribute. If the Flyers can replicate that formula on the road, they position themselves not only for a higher seed in the A-10 tournament but potentially for broader postseason consideration.

The immediate test comes quickly. Dayton now turns its focus to a pivotal road trip to face George Mason, a team ahead of them in the standings. Momentum is a fragile thing in February. The Flyers have it for now. The question is whether they can carry it with them out of UD Arena.

title: Road Test Awaits: Flyers Face Surging George Mason
description:
If Saturday’s win over Davidson stabilized Dayton’s season, Wednesday night’s trip to George Mason could redefine it.

The Flyers head to EagleBank Arena sitting at 7-5 in Atlantic 10 play, tied for fourth and within striking distance of the league’s upper tier. George Mason, however, represents one of the conference’s most consistent and disciplined teams this season. With a strong overall record and a 9-4 mark in league play, the Patriots have protected their home floor and imposed a physical, defense-first identity.

For Dayton, the keys are clear. The rebounding dominance displayed against Davidson must travel. On the road, possessions become even more valuable, and limiting second chances is critical. George Mason thrives on defensive stops and methodical half-court execution, often forcing opponents into late-clock decisions. Dayton cannot afford extended scoring droughts or careless turnovers.

Deshayne Montgomery’s return adds a layer of offensive versatility the Flyers sorely needed. His ability to create off the bounce could be a difference-maker against a set defense. Dayton will also need balanced scoring from its core rotation and disciplined shot selection to avoid fueling Mason’s transition game.

This matchup carries seeding implications. A road win would tighten the standings and give Dayton a valuable résumé boost inside the conference. A loss would not be fatal, but it would increase pressure in the remaining regular-season slate and narrow the margin for error heading into March.

The Flyers have shown they can rise to the moment. They have also shown vulnerability away from home. Wednesday’s contest is more than another conference game; it is a measuring stick. Are the Flyers merely competitive in the A-10, or are they prepared to contend?

In mid-February, answers matter. Dayton will get one under the bright lights in Fairfax.

title: Peru’s Revolving Door Presidency Deepens Crisis
description:
Peru is once again navigating political turbulence after Congress voted to remove interim President José Jerí in February 2026, marking the country’s eighth leadership change in roughly a decade. The move followed allegations that Jerí held undisclosed meetings with a Chinese businessman, a controversy that quickly escalated into a constitutional showdown in Lima.

Jerí had taken office only months earlier as a caretaker leader following the ousting of former President Dina Boluarte in late 2025. Lawmakers cited corruption concerns and a deteriorating security situation when they removed Boluarte, as Peru grappled with rising crime and growing public frustration. Her departure, once seen as a potential reset moment, instead underscored the fragility of Peru’s executive branch.

At the center of the current crisis is a constitutional mechanism that allows Congress to declare a president morally unfit for office. While designed as a safeguard, the clause has increasingly become a political weapon in a deeply fragmented legislature. Presidents have faced repeated impeachment threats, leaving administrations weakened and short-lived.

Public discontent has fueled much of the instability. Over the past two years, Peru has experienced sustained protests driven by younger voters and civic groups demanding accountability, economic reform, and improved public safety. Demonstrations have periodically paralyzed transportation corridors and drawn international scrutiny, reflecting widespread distrust of political elites.

Despite the turmoil, Peru’s broader economic fundamentals — anchored by mining exports and macroeconomic discipline — have remained relatively stable. However, investors are closely watching the country’s governance outlook, wary that prolonged uncertainty could dampen growth and foreign direct investment.

Attention now turns to the April 12, 2026 general election, which will determine both the presidency and a new Congress. The field is crowded and ideologically diverse, raising the likelihood of a runoff. Analysts say the vote represents a pivotal opportunity to restore institutional credibility — but only if the next administration can build durable coalitions in a historically divided legislature.

For ordinary Peruvians, the stakes extend beyond political drama. Rising crime, inflationary pressures, and uneven economic opportunity have sharpened demands for effective leadership. Whether the coming election can break the cycle of rapid presidential turnover remains uncertain.

What is clear is that Peru stands at a crossroads. Without structural reforms to strengthen party systems, clarify impeachment standards, and rebuild public trust, the nation risks remaining trapped in a pattern of short-lived governments and recurring crisis. The months ahead may determine whether Peru stabilizes its democracy — or continues its era of revolving-door presidencies.

title: Next Man Up: Bruskotter's Career Night Propels Raiders to Top of Horizon
description:
If you needed proof that the Wright State Raiders have the depth to make a serious run in March, look no further than Sunday afternoon at the Wolstein Center. With starting guard Solomon Callaghan sidelined by illness, the Raiders didn’t just survive against Cleveland State—they thrived, delivering a 102-90 masterclass that vaulted them back into sole possession of first place in the Horizon League.

The catalyst was unlikely, yet undeniable. Redshirt freshman Alex Bruskotter, thrust into the spotlight, responded with the poise of a seasoned veteran. Bruskotter erupted for a career-high 25 points in 28 minutes, showcasing the sharpshooting pedigree that once made him an Ohio Mr. Basketball finalist. His perfect 3-for-3 performance from deep wasn't just opportunistic; it was the backbone of an offensive clinic.

Wright State (17-10, 12-4 Horizon) operated with surgical precision, shooting a staggering 61.8% from the field. While Bruskotter grabbed the headlines, the supporting cast was relentless. TJ Burch continued to pilot the offense, facilitating ball movement that left the Vikings’ defense scrambling, while Michael Imariagbe and Michael Cooper ensured the Raiders controlled the interior. This wasn't a one-man show; it was a symphony of depth.

The timing of this surge is impeccable. having won five of their last seven, the Raiders control their own destiny with the regular season winding down. The No. 1 seed—and the crucial home-court advantage that comes with it—is theirs to lose.

The road to the title now runs through the Nutter Center. The Raiders return to Dayton this week for a pivotal homestand, hosting IU Indy on Wednesday before a massive showdown with Robert Morris on Saturday. If Sunday proved anything, it’s that Clint Sargent’s squad has the firepower and the 'next man up' mentality required to cut down the nets in Indianapolis.

title: Oxford Immortality: RedHawks Hit 26-0 After Gritty Road Win
description:
AMHERST, Mass. — The number next to Miami University’s name is no longer just a relic of the Wally Szczerbiak era; it is a warning to the rest of the college basketball world. 

No. 22 Miami (OH) extended the nation’s longest winning streak to 26 games on Tuesday night, outlasting Massachusetts 86-77 at the Mullins Center. With the victory, the RedHawks become the first Division I men’s basketball team to reach a 26-0 start since the 2020-21 Gonzaga Bulldogs, cementing their status as the premier story of the 2025-26 season.

Led by senior guard Peter Suder’s game-high 23 points, Miami neutralized a hostile road environment and a late second-half surge from the Minutemen. UMass briefly claimed a 62-60 lead with nine minutes remaining, but the RedHawks responded with the poise of a seasoned juggernaut. Sophomore floor general Luke Skaljac orchestrated the counter-attack, finishing with a game-high seven assists and hitting crucial free throws to ice the game. 

This historic run has revitalized a program that had not appeared in the AP Top 25 since February 15, 1999. Under head coach Travis Steele, the RedHawks have transformed into an offensive machine, currently leading the nation in scoring at 92.6 points per game. Steele’s high-tempo system has proved unsolvable for the Mid-American Conference, where Miami now stands at a perfect 13-0.

While skeptics highlight the team's strength of schedule, the analytics are beginning to validate the record. Miami’s offensive efficiency ranks in the top five nationally, and their ability to win in varied environments—including three overtime thrillers in January—suggests a deep-seated tournament resolve. 

The RedHawks return to a sold-out Millett Hall this Friday to host Bowling Green. If they can navigate their final five regular-season contests unscathed, they will enter the MAC Tournament with a chance to become the first team in decades to enter Selection Sunday with a perfect zero in the loss column.

title: Xenia's False Mass Cassualty: How an AI Alert System Caused Resident's Serious Concern
description:
XENIA, Ohio — For a frantic hour on Tuesday morning, residents of Xenia believed a mass casualty event was unfolding at their local Walmart. Social media feeds lit up with terrifying alerts, phones rang off the hook at the police station, and parents anxiously checked on their children. Yet, at the alleged scene, there were no sirens, no ambulances, and no emergency. The crisis was entirely digital—a phantom generated by a technological glitch that serves as a stark warning about our increasing reliance on automated information systems.

The chaos was triggered not by a malicious actor, but by a fundamental failure in artificial intelligence context recognition within a popular third-party application known as "Crime Radar." The app utilizes AI designed to transcribe and interpret real-time police scanner traffic, pushing alerts to users based on perceived keywords and urgency levels. On Tuesday, Xenia emergency services were conducting a scheduled, high-intensity triage training exercise. The scanner chatter was terrifyingly real, but the situation was simulated.

The Crime Radar AI, lacking the crucial human ability to discern context or recognize the designated codes indicating a drill, processed the simulation data as a real-world catastrophe. It immediately broadcasted a high-priority "Mass Casualty" alert to its subscriber base in Greene County. The speed at which this misinformation traveled highlights the volatility of the current digital ecosystem; within minutes, an algorithmic hallucination became a community-wide panic spread via Facebook and X.

Xenia authorities moved quickly to stem the tide of misinformation. Police officials confirmed that no officers were dispatched to the location because dispatchers and first responders were fully aware the radio traffic was related to the pre-planned training scenario. The disconnect was purely between the reality on the ground and the interpretation by the app's server.

This incident is not an anomaly. Similar false alarms triggered by AI-driven scanner apps have been reported recently in cities like Kansas City, exposing a critical flaw in the "move fast and automate everything" ethos. While artificial intelligence excels at pattern matching and data crunching, it woefully struggles with nuance and situational awareness—the very elements essential in emergency communication.

The Xenia incident serves as a necessary stress test for civic digital literacy. It demonstrates that while scraping raw data from public airwaves is technologically feasible, presenting that data as verified intelligence without human intervention is deeply irresponsible. Until these systems can reliably distinguish between a Tuesday morning drill and a genuine crisis, citizens are urged to verify terrifying alerts through official channels—local news outlets and verified government social media accounts—rather than trusting the unfiltered output of a smartphone algorithm.

title: Roar of the Wild: Bill Seeks Return of Elk to Ohio After 185-Year Absence
description: A sound absent from the Ohio woodlands for nearly two centuries could soon return to the Hocking Hills and Appalachian foothills. State lawmakers are currently reviewing House Bill 641, dubbed the “Trails and Tails Act,” a legislative push to determine if the Buckeye State is ready to reintroduce the Rocky Mountain elk. The Legislation: A Study, Not a Release Introduced in January 2026 by Rep. Justin Pizzulli (R-Scioto County), the bill does not immediately authorize the release of animals. Instead, it directs the Ohio Department of Natural Resources (ODNR) to utilize $1 million for a comprehensive feasibility study. The goal is to identify suitable habitats in southern Ohio—specifically reclaimed strip mines and state forests—where elk could thrive without encroaching on human population centers. The Incentive: Chasing the Kentucky Model The driving force behind HB 641 is economic. Proponents point to neighboring Kentucky, which successfully reintroduced elk in 1997. Today, Kentucky boasts the largest elk herd east of the Mississippi, generating millions of dollars annually through hunting lottery applications and eco-tourism. Lawmakers believe a similar program in Ohio could revitalize the economy of the state’s southern Appalachian region, drawing visitors to fill hotels, restaurants, and outdoor outfitters. The History: Why They Left Elk were once abundant across Ohio, but the majestic ungulates were victims of the state’s rapid 19th-century expansion. Unregulated market hunting and the mass clearing of forests for farmland drove the population to extinction. The last known native elk in Ohio was killed in 1841. Since then, the species has been absent, save for a few small, captive herds. The Controversy: Crops, Cars, and CWD Despite the enthusiasm from hunters and conservationists, the proposal faces significant hurdles. The agricultural lobby remains skeptical, citing concerns that free-ranging elk—which can weigh up to 800 pounds—could devastate row crops and destroy fencing. Additionally, biological concerns loom large. The ODNR has historically approached reintroduction with caution, primarily due to the threat of Chronic Wasting Disease (CWD), a fatal neurological illness affecting deer and elk. Importing a herd carries the risk of introducing new strains of the disease to Ohio’s massive white-tailed deer population, a risk state biologists take seriously. The study, if approved, is due to the Governor by December 2028.

title: Geneva's Fragile Handshake: Drafting a Deal Under Fire
description:
GENEVA — The second round of indirect negotiations between the United States and Iran concluded Tuesday with mediators reporting "good progress." In the rigid lexicon of international diplomacy, this signals a crucial, albeit procedural, breakthrough: the transition from airing grievances to drafting actual text. However, this diplomatic momentum is precariously balanced against a backdrop of intensifying military posturing and fundamental policy disagreements that threaten to unravel the entire process.

Through Omani intermediaries, US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, and Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi, agreed upon a set of "guiding principles." The immediate result is a two-week window for both capitals to exchange draft language before scheduling a third round. This shift towards identifying common technical goals is the most significant tangible movement between Washington and Tehran in years. It suggests a mutual desire, for now, to bypass an immediate escalation confrontation in favor of a negotiated off-ramp.

Yet, the split-screen reality of these talks cannot be ignored. The Geneva progress occurred simultaneously with aggressive signaling in the Persian Gulf. As diplomats convened, Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps conducted high-profile naval drills near the Strait of Hormuz, explicitly threatening closure of the vital waterway. Conversely, the continued presence of the USS Abraham Lincoln carrier strike group reinforces Washington's "maximum pressure" posture. Both sides are effectively negotiating while holding loaded weapons under the table.

The upcoming drafting phase will expose the massive substantive chasms remaining. The core dispute remains the nuclear fuel cycle. Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei recently reaffirmed Iran's "right" to enrichment, a stance seemingly incompatible with US demands for a near-zero capability. Furthermore, the Biden administration, facing pressure from hawks including VP JD Vance, insists any agreement must address Iran's ballistic missile arsenal and support for regional proxies—topics Tehran vehemently rejects as outside the negotiation's scope.

The "good progress" in Geneva is effectively a handshake agreement to keep trying. It proves both sides prefer arduous diplomacy to immediate conflict. But as they move from vague principles to precise treaty language, the technical reality of bridging their incompatible red lines will determine if Geneva represents the dawn of détente or merely a sophisticated delaying tactic.

title: McLaughlin Exits DHS Amid Chaos, Controversy & Agency Shutdown
description:
WASHINGTON — Tricia McLaughlin, the combative Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs at the Department of Homeland Security, resigned Tuesday, marking the end of a turbulent tenure that became the public face of the administration’s hardline immigration enforcement. Her departure comes at a moment of supreme vulnerability for the agency, which is currently paralyzed by a partial government shutdown and facing a cratering public approval rating.

While McLaughlin stated her exit had been planned since December 2025, the timing suggests a strategic retreat from a department under siege. The DHS is currently ground zero for a political firestorm following the fatal shootings of U.S. citizens Renee Good and Alex Pretti by ICE agents in Minneapolis. McLaughlin drew intense bipartisan criticism in the aftermath for prematurely labeling Pretti a "domestic terrorist"—a claim later walked back by agency heads but one that arguably poured gas on an already raging legislative fire.

That fire has now consumed the agency's funding. Since February 14, the DHS has operated under a partial shutdown, with Senate Democrats refusing to pass a funding bill without strict "guardrails" on ICE and CBP enforcement tactics. Approximately 90% of the department’s staff are currently working without pay, though enforcement operations continue under previously allocated funds.

McLaughlin’s resignation also removes a lightning rod for ethics watchdogs. House Democrats have been aggressively scrutinizing a $200 million DHS advertising contract awarded to a firm managed by her husband, Ben Yoho. Although McLaughlin maintained she was recused from the process, the optics of the deal provided endless ammunition for the administration's opponents.

Despite the change in personnel, a change in tone seems unlikely. McLaughlin will be succeeded by her deputy, Lauren Bis, with former Fox News commentator Katie Zacharia stepping in as Deputy Assistant Secretary. The promotion of Bis and the hiring of Zacharia signal that the White House intends to maintain its aggressive, media-forward posture on border security, even as polling shows approval for the agenda dipping to a net negative 20%.

McLaughlin leaves a legacy of polarized efficacy; she successfully amplified the administration’s "One Big Beautiful Bill" narrative but leaves behind an agency with frayed credibility and an uncertain financial future.

title: Bulls Blink: Tech Wobbly as Global Rates Cool
description: It's a Wednesday of mixed signals on Wall Street, where the unstoppable force of the AI boom is finally meeting the immovable object of valuation gravity. While the S&P 500 hovers near 6,843, clinging to its record highs, the real story is under the hood. The Nasdaq 100 has slipped 3.3% this month—a classic 'seasonal pullback' or the first crack in the semiconductor armor? Investors are jittery following reports that the PlayStation 6 launch could slide to 2028 due to AI-chip bottlenecks, a headline that sent tremors through the hardware sector overnight. The Global Pivot Across the Atlantic, the inflation fever has broken. The UK’s CPI print of 3.0% this morning wasn’t just good; it was a 'green light' for the Bank of England to consider cuts. Canada is telling a similar story at 2.3%. The message for the Fed is clear ahead of today’s FOMC minutes: the global tightening cycle is ending. The question is no longer 'if' rates fall, but 'when' the Fed acknowledges the goods inflation retreat. Deal Flow & Geopolitics The M&A landscape is equally chaotic. Paramount Global has reportedly entered a 'final seven-day' sprint to outflank Netflix for Warner Bros. Discovery, pushing bids north of $31/share. Meanwhile, the Japan-U.S. strategic alliance has yielded a massive $36 billion infrastructure pledge from Tokyo, aimed directly at American energy and critical minerals—a move likely to ruffle feathers in Beijing but bolster industrial plays here at home. The Bottom Line Watch the 10-year Treasury yield, currently sticky at 4.06%. If it dips on today's Fed minutes, the tech 'AI anxiety' could vanish as quickly as it arrived. But for now, caution is the only currency that matters.

title: Power Play: Japan's $36B Bet on American AI & Energy
description:
The check has cleared, and the message is unmistakable: Tokyo is buying into the American energy renaissance, and the price of admission is $36 billion. In a move that marries high finance with hard infrastructure, Japan has deployed the first tranche of its pledged $550 billion investment package, effectively trading capital for tariff relief in a deal that reshapes the trans-Pacific economic corridor.

While the headline figure is staggering, the allocation reveals a targeted strategy to secure the raw power required for the next industrial revolution. The crown jewel of this initiative lands right here in Ohio. A massive $33.3 billion represents the lion’s share of the funding, earmarked for a 9.2-gigawatt natural gas facility in Portsmouth. This isn't just another power plant; it is slated to be the largest of its kind in history, a monolithic energy engine designed specifically to feed the voracious electricity appetite of the Midwest’s booming AI data center ecosystem. Backed by SoftBank’s SB Energy, the project signals that data processing is now a heavy industry, requiring base-load power on a scale previously reserved for nation-states.

Simultaneously, the deal looks south to the Texas coast. Approximately $2.1 billion will flow into the Texas GulfLink deepwater terminal. This infrastructure play is pure arbitrage: streamlining the conduit for U.S. shale to reach Asian markets. Once operational, the terminal is projected to facilitate up to $30 billion in annual crude exports, effectively locking in Japan’s energy security while cementing American dominance in global oil trade.

Rounding out the trifecta is a $600 million injection into Georgia for synthetic diamond manufacturing by Element Six. While smaller in dollar value, its strategic weight is immense. Industrial diamond grit is the unsung hero of semiconductor manufacturing and quantum computing. By onshoring 100% of domestic demand, the U.S. and Japan are executing a surgical strike against reliance on Chinese supply chains for critical minerals.

Make no mistake, this is a transactional masterclass. The capital injection—structured largely through loans and guarantees via the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC)—secure Japan a reduced tariff rate of 15%, down from a threatened 25%. For the U.S., it delivers physical assets and blue-collar employment. For Japan, it ensures their auto industry remains competitive in the American market while their banks earn yield on the infrastructure loans. It is economic decoupling in practice, funded by one of the world's largest sovereign balance sheets.

title: The 'ChatGPT of Surgery': Hopkins Robot Learns by Watching
description:
A significant breakthrough in robotic surgery has emerged from Johns Hopkins University, where researchers are successfully training robots to perform complex procedures by having AI 'watch' archival videos of human surgeons at work. This move away from tedious, manual programming marks a fundamental shift in medical robotics.

The system, dubbed the Surgical Robot Transformer (SRT), utilizes the same architecture powering large language models like ChatGPT. However, instead of processing text, SRT interprets kinematics—the mathematical language of motion. The AI is trained via "imitation learning" using a massive archive of footage recorded by wrist-mounted cameras on da Vinci Surgical Systems, the primary robotic platform used globally. By analyzing thousands of hours of these expert recordings, the model translates visual inputs into precise robotic movements.

The results extend far beyond basic motor skills. In recent demonstrations, advanced iterations of the model mastered fundamental tasks such as suturing and tissue manipulation. Furthermore, it successfully completed multi-step procedures, including gallbladder removal on porcine tissue, with high accuracy. Critically, the system demonstrates significant adaptability: if the robot drops a needle, it recognizes the error, retrieves the instrument, and resumes the task autonomously.

This technology addresses a major bottleneck in medical automation. Where programming a robot for a single procedure once took years of hand-coding, training can now potentially occur in days using existing video data. By democratizing the skills of top-tier surgeons, these systems aim to eventually standardize surgical outcomes and reduce human error. The trajectory points toward human clinical trials and increased surgical autonomy within the coming decade.

title: Comedy Titan Katt Williams Brings 'The Golden Age' Tour to Nutter Center
description:
FAIRBORN, Ohio — Comedy fans, mark your calendars. The legendary and often controversial stand-up titan Katt Williams is set to light up the stage at the Wright State University Nutter Center on Friday, April 3, 2026.

Arriving as part of his massive nationwide trek, "The Golden Age Tour," Williams returns to the Gem City area following a blockbuster run in 2025 with his "Heaven on Earth" shows. Known for his electric energy and razor-sharp social commentary, the Cincinnati-born comic promises an evening of entirely new material that pulls no punches.

"The Golden Age Tour" comes hot on the heels of his recent viral successes and streaming specials, which have dominated charts and reignited conversations across the entertainment world. Organizers for the Nutter Center event indicate that Williams is performing at the peak of his powers, delivering a set that blends his signature theatrical delivery with biting insights on modern culture, politics, and race.

Tickets for the 8:00 PM show are currently on sale and moving briskly. Prices for the Fairborn engagement start around $108 for upper-level seating, with floor seats commanding premium pricing. Fans looking to attend are encouraged to purchase sooner rather than later, as Williams has a history of selling out arenas across Ohio. Secondary market tickets are available but may carry significant markups as the date approaches.

Doors are expected to open approximately 60 to 90 minutes prior to showtime. Attendees should anticipate heavy traffic along Colonel Glenn Highway and are advised to arrive early to secure parking at the Nutter Center lots.

Don't miss this chance to see one of the most vital voices in comedy live in action. Whether you're a longtime follower of his "The Pimp Chronicles" era or a new fan drawn in by his recent viral moments, April 3rd promises to be a night of unforgettable laughter.

title: Morning Commute Nightmare: DPS Bus Crash Closes Smithville, Students Evaluated
description:
A frightening scene unfolded early Wednesday morning as a Dayton Public Schools bus was involved in a significant collision on South Smithville Road, just yards from Kemp Elementary School. The crash, which occurred shortly before 8:00 a.m., drew a massive response from Dayton Police and Fire emergency crews, effectively paralyzing traffic in one of East Dayton’s busiest corridors.

According to preliminary reports from the scene, the yellow school bus was transporting students for the morning drop-off when it collided with a sedan near the intersection of Smithville and Arlene Avenue. Witnesses reported hearing a loud screech of tires followed by a heavy impact that shattered the morning calm. "It shook the front windows," said resident Gary Miller, who lives two blocks away. "I ran out and saw steam rising from the car and the bus skewed across the double yellow lines."

First responders acted swiftly, setting up a triage area on the roadside. While specific injury counts remain under official review, Dayton Fire Department personnel were seen evaluating multiple students for potential whiplash and bruises. Critically, no life-threatening injuries have been reported among the students or the drivers involved as of 9:00 a.m. Parents of the students on board were immediately notified via the district's automated OneCall system, and a relief bus was dispatched to transport uninjured students to their school to begin their day and meet with counselors.

South Smithville Road remains closed in both directions between US-35 and Patterson Road while accident reconstruction teams map the scene and tow trucks work to clear the wreckage. Commuters are advised to seek alternate routes, utilizing Watervliet Avenue or Wayne Avenue to navigate around the closure. The cause of the crash is still under investigation, though slick spots from morning condensation are being looked at as a contributing factor. This marks the second serious traffic incident in this specific stretch of Smithville in February, raising fresh questions about traffic calming measures near school zones.

title: Protecting the Peak: Raiders Return Home to Defend First Place vs. IU Indy
description: FAIRBORN, Ohio — If you glance solely at the Horizon League standings, Thursday night’s matchup at the Nutter Center looks like a formality. On one side, you have the Wright State Raiders (17-10, 12-4), sitting comfortably in the driver’s seat for the regular-season conference title. On the other, the IU Indy Jaguars (7-21, 3-14), a team anchored near the basement of the league. But if you’ve been watching the tape, you know that this is exactly the kind of game that gives coaches ulcers. The Stakes Have Never Been Higher With just four games remaining in the regular season, Wright State holds a precious two-game lead over Oakland. The math is simple: keep winning, and the road to the NCAA Tournament goes through Fairborn. A slip-up now, however, opens the door for the Golden Grizzlies to steal the No. 1 seed. The Raiders are fresh off an offensive masterclass against Cleveland State on Sunday, where they dropped 102 points in a frantic road victory. Redshirt freshman Alex Bruskotter was a revelation, pouring in 25 points off the bench. It was the kind of performance that suggests this team is peaking at the right time. But here is the rub: the defense gave up 90 points. And that is where the Jaguars become dangerous. The "Scary" Underdog Don't let the 7-21 record deceive you. IU Indy is playing desperate, spirited basketball. They arrive in Dayton on a three-game losing streak, but look at the margins: they have lost those three games by a combined total of just 12 points. On Sunday, they nearly pulled off the impossible, erasing a 21-point deficit against Purdue Fort Wayne before falling 83-78. They have a legitimate star in junior Kyler D'Augustino, who is averaging 18.8 points per game. Raiders fans should remember him well; he torched Wright State for 31 points in their first meeting on Jan. 4, a game the Raiders narrowly escaped with an 81-77 win. Key Matchup to Watch Wright State’s Perimeter Defense vs. Micah Davis & Kyler D'Augustino While Wright State’s Michael Cooper and Bruskotter provide plenty of firepower, the game will be decided on the other end. IU Indy sophomore Micah Davis is coming off a 23-point explosion. If the Raiders trade baskets like they did against Cleveland State, this game will be uncomfortably close in the final four minutes. The Bottom Line Wright State has been resilient, bouncing back from a tough loss to Detroit Mercy earlier this month to reclaim their swagger. But the Nutter Center crowd needs to bring the energy Thursday night. This is the classic "trap game"—sandwiched between a massive road win and a looming showdown with Robert Morris on Sunday. Expect the Raiders to win, but don’t expect it to be easy. In February, no one rolls over.

title: Walking the Macro Tightrope: Why Today's Green Tape Hides a Deeper Struggle
description: Markets are up, but don't exhale just yet. While the screens are flashing green this Wednesday—led by a resurgent Nasdaq (+1.26%) and a high-profile partnership between Meta and Nvidia—savvy traders know better than to take price action at face value in this environment. We are currently witnessing a market in the midst of a complex structural rotation, caught in a gray area that defies simple "bull" or "bear" labels. The Inflation/Deflation Tug-of-War The macro thesis governing this market is stark but essential to understand. If we see inflation stabilize at a healthy pace, asset prices and CPI should theoretically grind higher. However, the risk of the inverse—deflation—remains the elephant in the room. A deflationary spiral would drag asset prices down with it, a scenario that could be catastrophic for equity valuations. Currently, we are stuck in the uncomfortable middle: a state of disinflation paired with thinning liquidity. This environment makes sustained rallies difficult to trust, as the capital required to fuel a broad-based breakout simply isn't there. The Bull Case: GDP and Real Assets Challenging the bearish liquidity view is the undeniably robust economic data. GDP remains high, defying recession calls, and we are seeing significant, tangible investment in materials and infrastructure. This capital expenditure is creating a floor for the market, preventing the bottom from falling out. It’s no coincidence that while Tech grabs the headlines, Energy (+1.24%) and industrial materials are quietly catching a bid alongside Crude Oil today. There is a chance these real-economy forces balance out the monetary tightening, carrying the markets higher through sheer economic inertia. The Timeline: Waiting for November My theory? This chop is the new normal until the Fed meeting in June and if they don't cut rates then it will continue until after the midterm elections later this year. We are seeing a massive restructuring of portfolios—a rotation rather than an exodus. Yesterday, the narrative was fear; today, it is relief. But until we see a definitive shift in the liquidity picture, today's rally is likely just another swing of the pendulum rather than the start of a new paradigm. Bottom Line Today's move is a welcome reprieve, but the question remains: Can this rally hold? In a liquidity-constrained environment with a disinflationary headwind, the ceiling is lower than it looks. Trade the rotation, respect the GDP data, but keep one eye on the deflationary risks lurking in the shadows.

title: Palantir Ditches Rockies for Sunshine State, Joins Growing Tech Exodus
description: In a move that has once again sent ripples through the tech industry, data analytics giant Palantir Technologies has officially announced it is relocating its global headquarters from Denver, Colorado, to Miami, Florida. This decision marks the second major corporate relocation for the company in just six years, having originally departed its foundational home in Silicon Valley for the Rocky Mountains in 2020. According to recent SEC filings, Palantir's new principal executive offices will be located in Aventura, an affluent suburb situated just north of Miami. The sudden announcement appears to have caught Colorado officials by surprise, with Governor Jared Polis reportedly receiving no advance notice of the company's impending departure. While Palantir's public statements have been somewhat subdued, regulatory filings suggest the move was prompted by a mix of factors. The company specifically cited Colorado's recently enacted artificial intelligence legislation as being potentially "onerous and costly," and also noted concerns regarding climate-related risks in the West, such as wildfires and chronic water scarcity. Palantir's southward migration is far from an isolated event; it is the latest chapter in a much larger, multi-year narrative of tech companies and their billionaire founders fleeing traditional hubs for more business-friendly pastures. Florida, with its complete lack of state income tax and an increasingly pro-tech regulatory environment, has become a primary beneficiary of this so-called "Silicon Valley Exodus." Palantir joins a notable roster of major players that have shifted significant operations away from California in recent years, a list that includes Tesla, Oracle, and hedge fund powerhouse Citadel. This persistent trend is driven by a confluence of hard economic and political realities. Extremely high taxes, exorbitant housing costs, and a perceived hostile regulatory climate in California have pushed many firms to seek out states like Texas and Florida, which offer lower operating overhead and a more welcoming approach to business. The move also reflects a symbolic shift in the industry's power dynamics, as key figures like Palantir co-founder Peter Thiel have already established significant personal and professional footholds in South Florida, signaling that the center of gravity for tech leadership is no longer solely confined to the San Francisco Bay Area. While Silicon Valley remains the undisputed world leader for startup density and venture capital funding, Palantir's departure reinforces a new post-pandemic reality: top-tier tech companies can now thrive—and are increasingly choosing to build their futures—far from the coastal hub where the industry was born.

title: Zuckerberg Takes the Stand: Meta CEO Grilled in Landmark 'Digital Casino' Child Addiction Trial
description: LOS ANGELES — In a courtroom packed with grieving parents and watched closely by the tech industry, Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg took the stand on Wednesday in a watershed trial that could redefine the legal liability of social media giants. The chief executive faced a barrage of questions regarding allegations that his company intentionally designed Instagram and Facebook to be addictive to children, prioritizing corporate growth over the mental health of a generation. This bellwether trial, taking place in Los Angeles Superior Court, centers on the lawsuit brought by a 20-year-old woman identified only as "K.G.M." or "Kaley." The plaintiff alleges that she began using the platforms at age nine and subsequently spiraled into severe depression, anxiety, and suicidal ideation fueled by the apps' "defective design." Her attorneys argue that features such as the "infinite scroll," intermittent variable rewards (likes), and beauty filters were engineered to exploit the vulnerabilities of developing brains—likening the apps to "digital casinos" meant to keep users hooked. "These companies built machines designed to addict the brains of children," said lead plaintiff attorney Mark Lanier during opening statements. "And they did it on purpose." Under oath, Zuckerberg was confronted with internal Meta documents that plaintiffs claim show a clear discrepancy between the company’s public safety rhetoric and its internal strategy. Attorneys grilled the CEO on whether he directed his teams to ignore warnings from their own researchers about the harms of Instagram on teen body image and mental well-being in favor of metrics that drove engagement and ad revenue. Zuckerberg, appearing stoic, maintained that Meta has introduced over 30 tools to support teen supervision and wellbeing, arguing that the platforms provide essential social connection. "The evidence will show our longstanding commitment to supporting young people," a Meta spokesperson said prior to the testimony. However, the defense's argument—that social media was merely a coping mechanism for K.G.M.'s pre-existing struggles rather than the cause—faced stiff skepticism from the plaintiff's legal team, who pointed to the sheer volume of hours the algorithms kept the user engaged. The stakes of this trial extend far beyond a single verdict. It serves as a test case for thousands of similar lawsuits consolidated across the country, filed by school districts and families who say their children were harmed or even died due to social media-related issues. While other defendants like TikTok and Snap settled before trial, Meta and Google (YouTube) remain. A verdict against Zuckerberg's company could force a fundamental redesign of how social media operates in the United States.

title: National Park Outrage: Lawsuit Claims Park Service Censoring Slavery and Climate Exhibits
description: BOSTON — A broad coalition of historical and environmental organizations filed a federal lawsuit Tuesday against the Department of the Interior and the National Park Service (NPS), accusing the administration of an unlawful campaign to "erase history and science" from America’s national parks. The suit, filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts, challenges the implementation of the administration's contentious "Restoring Truth and Sanity to American History" executive order. The plaintiffs, represented by the legal nonprofit Democracy Forward, include the National Parks Conservation Association (NPCA), the Union of Concerned Scientists, and the Association of National Park Rangers. They allege that since the order was issued in March 2025, park rangers and superintendents have been forced to remove or alter exhibits that discuss slavery, civil rights, the displacement of Indigenous peoples, and climate change, under the guise of removing "divisive narratives." "You cannot tell the story of America without recognizing both the beauty and the tragedy of our history," said Skye Perryman, President of Democracy Forward. "Censoring facts does not make them go away; it only deprives the public of the truth." The lawsuit details specific instances of alleged censorship that have sparked outrage. At the President's House site in Philadelphia, an exhibit detailing the lives of nine enslaved people in George Washington's household was ordered removed—a decision a federal judge already blocked in a separate emergency ruling on Monday. At Glacier National Park and Acadia National Park, the suit claims that signage explaining the science of melting glaciers and rising temperatures was stripped away or rewritten to downplay the human role in climate change. Further allegations point to the removal of displays at the Grand Canyon regarding the forced removal of Native American tribes, and the flagging of materials at the Selma to Montgomery National Historic Trail for discussing systemic racism. The lawsuit argues these actions violate the National Park Service Organic Act, which mandates the preservation of resources unimpaired for future generations, and the Administrative Procedure Act, by acting arbitrarily and capriciously to override established historical and scientific consensus. The administration has defended the policy as a necessary corrective to what it terms "partisan ideology" infiltrating public lands. Interior Secretary Doug Burgum previously stated the goal was to ensure monuments do not "inappropriately disparage Americans past or living." However, the lawsuit contends that the policy has created a culture of fear among NPS staff, forcing career civil servants to choose between their duty to the truth and their livelihoods. "Censoring science and erasing America's history at national parks are direct threats to everything these amazing places stand for," stated Alan Spears, Senior Director of Cultural Resources for the NPCA. The group is seeking a permanent injunction to halt the removals and restore the original educational materials.

title: Bond Market Tremors: 20-Year Treasury Auction 'Broken' as Demand Evaporates
description: Wall Street received a stark wake-up call Wednesday afternoon as the US Treasury’s latest auction of 20-year bonds ended in what traders are describing as a “disaster.” The results underscore a growing fragility in the market for US government debt, particularly for less popular durations, and signal potential turbulence ahead for borrowing costs. The Anatomy of a Failure The Treasury offered $16 billion in 20-year bonds, a seemingly routine operation that quickly turned ugly. The auction “tailed” significantly—a term used when the final yield is higher than the market price at the bidding deadline. The high yield settled at 4.664%, nearly 3 basis points above the “When-Issued” level. In the world of fixed income, a gap of this magnitude is considered a serious rejection of the Treasury's initial pricing. Even more concerning were the demand metrics. The bid-to-cover ratio, a primary gauge of investor appetite, plummeted to 2.36, well below the six-auction average of 2.58. This indicates that for every dollar of debt offered, there were significantly fewer buyers than usual. Consequently, Primary Dealers—the banks obligated to buy any unsold debt—were forced to absorb a larger-than-normal share, leaving them holding bags of depreciating bonds. The 'Orphan' Maturity Problem While today’s volatility is partly due to broader macro anxiety, the 20-year bond itself is a structural culprit. Reintroduced in 2020, this maturity has struggled to find a natural buyer base. Pension funds prefer the long duration of the 30-year bond to match liabilities, while traders prefer the liquidity of the 10-year note. The 20-year sits in an uncomfortable “no man’s land,” suffering from illiquidity that exacerbates sell-offs during moments of market stress. Fed Anxiety Looms Large Timing played a cruel role in today's poor showing. The auction concluded just hours before the release of the Federal Reserve’s January meeting minutes. With inflation data remaining sticky and headlines circulating regarding governance probes into Fed leadership, investors are paralyzed by uncertainty. The reluctance to lock up capital for two decades, just before potentially hawkish news from the central bank, was palpable on the trading desks. Why It Matters to You This isn't just inside baseball for bond traders. When Treasury auctions fail, yields spike. Since US Treasuries serve as the benchmark for global borrowing, a spike here ripples outward immediately. Mortgage rates, auto loans, and corporate debt are all priced off these curves. Today’s auction suggests that the cost of financing the US deficit is rising, and the market is demanding a higher premium to hold America’s long-term debt.

title: Sinclair's Spring Surge: Enrollment Hits 13-Year High
description: In a higher education landscape still finding its footing post-pandemic, Sinclair Community College is sprinting. The downtown Dayton institution has recorded its highest Spring term enrollment in 13 years, a significant milestone that signals a successful realignment of its academic strategy with regional workforce demands. As the Spring 2026 semester gets underway, Sinclair reports a total headcount exceeding 20,300 students. This represents a 3% year-over-year growth and the strongest spring showing since 2013. The surge builds on substantial momentum from last fall, which saw a decade-high enrollment of over 20,600 students. This growth is not merely a rebound; it is the result of deliberate structural shifts designed to remove barriers for modern students. Perhaps the most impactful operational change is the introduction of a multi-semester viewable schedule. This allows working adults and parents—a core demographic for Sinclair—to plan their academic lives a full year in advance, providing necessary predictability. Consequently, returning student re-enrollment jumped 8%. Furthermore, Sinclair is aggressively redefining the traditional community college model by expanding its Applied Bachelor’s Degrees. Offering four-year credentials in high-demand fields like Aviation Technology, Nursing, and the Internet of Things (IoT) at community college tuition rates has proven highly attractive. Enrollment in these bachelor programs grew by a massive 25% this term. The college’s strategy is tightly coupled with Dayton's economic future.
