This academic year, Sinclair launched seven new degree and certificate programs specifically tailored to regional needs in advanced manufacturing and cybersecurity. This commitment to future-proofing the local workforce is underscored by a recently announced $30 million investment to transform Building 8 into a state-of-the-art Integrated Technology Education Center, focusing on AI and robotics training. The enrollment spike is broad-based. International student recruitment recovered significantly with 20% growth, while the College Credit Plus program continues to dominate, expected to serve over 12,000 high school students this year. By maintaining its status as Ohio's most affordable community college while simultaneously upgrading its credential offerings and technology infrastructure, Sinclair has positioned itself as the undisputed engine of workforce development for the Miami Valley.

title: Wexner Breaks Silence: 'I Was Naive' — But The Shadow Remains
description: NEW ALBANY, Ohio — The black SUVs arrived early this morning, cutting through the heavy mist that hung over the manicured hedgerows of New Albany. They weren't carrying shoppers or fashion executives, but members of the U.S. House Oversight Committee. Today, February 18, 2026, Leslie "Les" Wexner—the 88-year-old architect of the modern shopping mall and Ohio's wealthiest resident—is finally talking. In a closed-door deposition at his estate, just a stone's throw from the headquarters of the empire he built, Wexner is answering questions under oath about his decades-long financial and personal entanglement with Jeffrey Epstein. Ahead of the testimony, Wexner released a statement that was equal parts defiant and contrite. "I was naïve, foolish, and gullible to put any trust in Jeffrey Epstein," the statement read. "He was a con man. And while I was conned, I have done nothing wrong and have nothing to hide." It is a striking image: The Lion of Retail, now nearing 90, forced to defend his legacy against the ghost of a predator he claims to have cut ties with nearly 20 years ago. But for us in Dayton, the story of Les Wexner is more personal. Before the billions, before the mansions, and long before the scandals, he was just a kid from the Gem City. The Dayton Origin Story While Columbus claims him now, Les Wexner was born here in Dayton on September 8, 1937. He grew up watching his parents, Harry and Bella, grind out a living in the local retail scene. They were the original scrappy entrepreneurs, and it was in their shadow that Les learned the trade. The family moved to Columbus in 1951 to open a store named "Leslie's" (after their son), but it was Les who had the vision to break the mold. In 1963, he took a risk that would change global commerce. He borrowed $5,000 from an aunt to open a store that sold only women’s sportswear—no dresses, no coats. He called it "The Limited." The Merlin of the Mall That singular idea exploded into a retail galaxy. Wexner didn't just sell clothes; he sold fantasies. He bought a struggling San Francisco chain called Victoria's Secret and transformed it into a cultural juggernaut. He built Bath & Body Works, Abercrombie & Fitch, and Express. For forty years, if you bought a sweater or a candle in America, you probably bought it from Les Wexner. A Legacy in Twilight But today's deposition reminds us that you cannot buy your way out of history. The new unredacted files released by the Justice Department this year have raised uncomfortable questions about how deep the ties between Wexner and Epstein truly ran. Did the financier just manage the billionaire's money, or did he wield influence over the brands themselves? Wexner maintains he was a victim of Epstein's fraud, a man betrayed by a "world-class con man." As he sits in that room today, answering questions that could redefine his final chapter, Daytonians are left with a complex picture: The hometown boy who conquered the world, only to find his monument permanently stained by the company he kept.

title: Vatican Delivers Diplomatic Snub to Trump's "Board of Peace"
description: The Vatican, ROME — The Holy See has formally declined an invitation to become a founding member of President Trump’s controversial "Board of Peace," dealing a significant diplomatic blow to the administration’s attempt to forge a new, parallel international mediation body. Vatican Secretary of State, Cardinal Pietro Parolin, confirmed the decision on Tuesday, citing a fundamental commitment to established multilateral institutions over this new, Washington-led initiative. In explaining the refusal, Cardinal Parolin emphasized that the Vatican’s participation would be inconsistent with its "particular nature" as a neutral moral entity rather than a conventional geopolitical actor. The Holy See maintains that the United Nations should remain the primary forum for resolving global crises and expressed concern that a rival body, chaired indefinitely by a single world leader, could undermine the UN's legitimacy. Parolin also noted the Vatican's "perplexity" regarding the Board’s unique structure, which includes a reported $1 billion financial commitment for permanent membership—a fee the Vatican stated it would not pay. The "Board of Peace" was initially conceived by President Trump following the October 2025 Gaza ceasefire to oversee reconstruction. However, Trump has since expanded its mandate into a global conflict mediation body, positioning himself as its Chairman for Life with significant authority over its agenda and membership. The initiative has drawn a mixed international response. While nations such as Israel and Saudi Arabia have joined, many Western allies remain skeptical. Major players like Italy and the European Union have opted to attend the inaugural meeting only as observers, wary of the Board's unilateral architecture. This rejection highlights a deepening philosophical divergence between Pope Leo XIV, the first American pontiff, and the Trump administration. While both leaders prioritize peace diplomacy, their methods are increasingly at odds. The Pope advocates for inclusive, multilateral dialogue within existing frameworks, whereas the President favors a transactional, executive-led approach that frequently bypasses traditional diplomatic channels. The Vatican's firm "no" signals a significant resistance from established moral power centers to the administration's attempt to unilaterally reshape the global diplomatic landscape.

title: Geneva Grimace: Ukraine Peace Talks End in Deadlock and Recrimination
description: GENEVA — Two days of intense, U.S.-mediated negotiations in Geneva between Russia and Ukraine have concluded not with a breakthrough, but with a palpable deepening of the diplomatic chasm. The talks, the third round this year, wrapped up abruptly on Wednesday, leaving Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy visibly frustrated and the prospect of peace as distant as ever as the war nears its fourth anniversary next week. While the Trump administration projected an aura of "meaningful progress" from afar, the reality inside the negotiating room was far starker. The final session reportedly lasted barely two hours, a brevity that speaks volumes about the current impasse. Both sides characterized the discussions as "difficult," a diplomatic euphemism for a near-total lack of convergence on core issues. The presence of Vladimir Medinsky, a known Kremlin hardliner, as Russia's lead negotiator was widely interpreted by Western officials as a clear signal that Moscow has no immediate intention of compromising on its maximalist war goals. President Zelenskyy did not hide his dissatisfaction with the outcome. In the aftermath, he voiced acute frustration with what he perceived as deliberate Russian delaying tactics, accusing Moscow of dragging out a process that he believes could have been nearing a conclusion. More critically, he pushed back against what he termed "unfair" public pressure from Washington for Ukrainian concessions, arguing that a similar level of scrutiny was not being applied to the aggressor's stance. He reiterated a fundamental domestic political reality: any final peace deal involving territorial changes would require approval via a national referendum, making unilateral concessions by his government politically impossible. The primary sticking point remains territorial control. Russia continues to demand the full withdrawal of Ukrainian forces from the Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson, and Zaporizhzhia regions—including vast areas its troops do not currently occupy militarily. Kyiv remains steadfast in its refusal to cede sovereign territory. The fate of the Russian-occupied Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant further complicates matters, with no agreement reached on its demilitarization or return to Ukrainian control. Despite the overarching gloom, there was a sliver of technical progress reported. Discussions regarding the practical mechanics of a potential future ceasefire monitoring mission were described as "constructive." Zelenskyy noted that any such mechanism would likely involve direct U.S. oversight on the ground, a significant potential shift in America's role. However, without agreement on the fundamental political and territorial questions, these technical details remain largely theoretical. As delegations return to their respective capitals to "update their leaders," the failed Geneva round serves as a sobering reminder that the gap between diplomatic ambition and the entrenched realities of the war remains immense.

title: A Taste of Spring: Basking in Wednesday's Record-Tying Warmth
description: What a spectacular gift this week has been, Dayton. Before we batten down the hatches for tonight's severe weather and the inevitable plunge back into the freezer, we need to take a collective moment to appreciate the absolute stunner of a day we experienced yesterday. Wednesday was the kind of glorious, mid-February afternoon that practically begged you to play hooky. It was the perfect excuse to roll down the car windows, take a sunny drive up to Huber Heights just to check on the construction progress at the new Buc-ee's, and let the breeze clear out the winter cobwebs. Shattering Expectations (and Records) If you stepped outside and thought the air felt historically pleasant, you were entirely correct. The mercury climbed all the way to a beautiful 66 degrees yesterday afternoon. According to the National Weather Service in Wilmington, that officially tied the record high for February 18th, which was last set back in 2017. Even our morning was remarkably mild. We woke up to a low of 50 degrees, which completely shattered the previous 'warmest low' record of 49 degrees set in 1981. It has been an incredibly unseasonable, spring-like stretch all week long across the Miami Valley. Heavy winter parkas have been eagerly traded for light sweaters, and local parks have been bustling with residents desperate to break free from their seasonal cabin fever. A Much-Needed Mental Boost There is something uniquely special about these 'false springs' we occasionally get treated to in Ohio. They are fleeting, of course, but they offer a vital morale boost right when the late-winter doldrums usually start to feel the heaviest. Whether you spent yesterday afternoon taking a long walk, grabbing a rare February lunch on an outdoor patio, or simply enjoying the fresh air drifting through an open office window, it was a spectacular preview of the warmer seasons ahead. So, as the harsh cold front prepares to sweep through later today and snap us sharply back to reality, let's not mourn the loss of our temporary spring. Instead, let's just be deeply appreciative that Mother Nature gave us a beautiful, 66-degree Wednesday to enjoy right in the middle of February.

title: Flyers Blitz Patriots 82-67, Snap Road Skid
description: FAIRFAX, VA — The University of Dayton men's basketball team delivered a resounding statement on Wednesday night, routing the George Mason Patriots 82-67 at EagleBank Arena. Fueled by a blistering shooting performance and a stifling defense, the Flyers commanded the game from the opening tip, securing a much-needed road victory. Javon Bennett was the offensive catalyst for Dayton (17-9, 8-5 A-10), pouring in a game-high 22 points. Bennett was lethal from beyond the arc, draining 5 of his 9 three-point attempts, while adding two assists and two steals. Big man Amaël L'Etang delivered a dominant performance in the paint, scoring a season-high 21 points on an incredibly efficient 9-of-11 shooting, alongside six rebounds. De'Shayne Montgomery and Keonte Jones added 10 and 8 points, respectively, helping Dayton shoot a season-best 55.8% from the floor. Dayton established control early, utilizing an 11-3 opening run to build a 43-36 halftime advantage. When George Mason cut the deficit to five early in the second half, the Flyers responded emphatically. Back-to-back three-point possessions, highlighted by a deep ball from L'Etang and a traditional three-point play from Montgomery, quickly pushed the lead back to double digits. In total, Dayton sank 11 three-pointers on 52.4% shooting from deep, completely neutralizing the Patriots' home-court advantage. George Mason (21-6, 9-5 A-10), led by Jahari Long's 17 points and Fatt Hill's 15, struggled to match Dayton's offensive firepower. The Patriots committed only nine turnovers but could not overcome Dayton's size advantage, as the Flyers dominated the paint 34-26. Beyond the final score, this victory carries significant weight for the Flyers' season trajectory. It successfully snapped a four-game road losing streak and ended a frustrating four-game skid against George Mason, marking Dayton's first win in Fairfax since the 2019-2020 campaign. The win also tightens the race in the upper echelon of the Atlantic 10 standings. Dayton now sits just a half-game behind George Mason for third place in the conference. Meanwhile, the Patriots, who started the season an incredible 18-1, find themselves in a sudden freefall, having lost three straight and four of their last five contests. The Flyers will look to carry this momentum back to UD Arena as they prepare for the season's final stretch.

title: The Enforcement Bottleneck: When Security Directives Collide with Judicial Reality
description: The administration has ushered in a fundamental shift in American immigration policy this week, moving away from a presumption of settled status for refugees and toward a model of continuous, stringent vetting. However, the aggressive rollout of this policy has exposed a critical vulnerability: the federal government's legal apparatus is buckling under the weight of its own enforcement actions. On Wednesday, a new Department of Homeland Security directive, authored by acting ICE Director Todd Lyons and USCIS Director Joseph Edlow, was made public. The February 18 memo formally rescinds a 2010 policy that protected refugees from detention if they failed to apply for a green card after one year of residency. Under the new rules, the one-year mark is now a mandatory re-vetting point. Refugees who have not secured permanent residency face arrest, indefinite detention, and a secondary screening for fraud or national security risks. From a national security standpoint, the executive branch's rationale is straightforward: admission to the United States should not be a blank check. If the initial vetting process was flawed, or if a refugee poses a latent risk, the government has a duty to identify and address that threat. The policy effectively transforms refugee status from a stable pathway to citizenship into a conditional, heavily scrutinized contract. But a policy is only as effective as the government's capacity to lawfully execute it. In Minnesota, the epicenter of the administration's aggressive 'Operation Metro Surge', the limits of that capacity are on full display. On the same day the DHS memo surfaced, U.S. District Judge Laura Provinzino held a Justice Department attorney in civil contempt of court. The lawyer, Matthew Isihara—a military judge advocate detailed to assist a severely strained U.S. Attorney's Office—was fined $500 per day for failing to return identification documents to Rigoberto Soto Jimenez, a man the judge had previously ordered released from ICE custody. Isihara cited overwhelming caseloads and a flooded system as the reason the case fell through the cracks. This incident in Minnesota is not an isolated bureaucratic hiccup; it is a symptom of a systemic bottleneck. The federal court system is facing a tsunami of habeas corpus petitions as thousands of legally admitted refugees are swept into detention centers. The DOJ is so understaffed that it is relying on military lawyers to handle civil immigration dockets, and judges are growing increasingly frustrated with the government's inability to comply with basic court orders. For conservative institutionalists, this presents a significant dilemma. Robust immigration enforcement and national sovereignty are foundational priorities, but so are the rule of law and the orderly administration of justice. The contempt ruling in Minnesota highlights a dangerous imbalance: the executive branch's speed in enacting enforcement sweeps is radically outpacing its legal and administrative infrastructure. When ICE violates court orders—nearly 100 times in January alone, according to Chief Judge Patrick Schiltz in Minnesota—it undermines the legitimacy of the enforcement effort itself. If the government cannot process the people it detains, return their property when ordered, or mount a timely legal defense of its actions, it risks turning a policy designed for national security into a chaotic exercise in state overreach. Ultimately, a zero-trust model for immigration requires a high-capacity, well-oiled legal machine to function properly. Until the administration can bridge the massive gap between its enforcement ambitions and its courtroom capabilities, the collision between sweeping DHS directives and frustrated federal judges will only intensify.

title: Deere Plows to Record High, Signals 'Bottom of Cycle'
description: John Deere (DE) shares roared to an all-time high on Thursday, surging more than 12% to an intraday peak of $672.95. The industrial giant stunned Wall Street with a fiscal first-quarter earnings report that not only shattered expectations but also offered a confident forecast that the worst of the agricultural machinery slump is likely behind it. At the core of the rally was a blistering financial performance that defied bearish sentiment. Deere reported adjusted earnings per share of $2.42, well clear of the $2.02 analyst consensus. Total revenue climbed 13% to $9.61 billion, blowing past projections that had topped out around $9.12 billion. Crucially, this strength did not come from the company's traditional bread-and-butter of large-scale farming equipment, which remains under pressure. Instead, Deere showcased impressive resilience through diversification. The Construction & Forestry segment was a standout, with net sales jumping 34% and operating profit more than doubling. Similarly, the Small Agriculture & Turf division saw sales rise 24%, driven by robust demand for smaller tractors and professional mowing gear. Beyond the backward-looking numbers, it was management's forward guidance that truly ignited the stock. CEO John May declared that the company views 2026 as the "bottom of the current cycle," setting the stage for renewed growth. Bolstering this view, Deere raised its full-year net income forecast to a range of $4.5 billion to $5.0 billion, a significant bump from its previous guidance of $4.0 billion to $4.75 billion. The company also noted successful progress in clearing dealer inventory, paving the way for new orders. Adding to the bullish narrative is Deere's aggressive push into next-generation technology. Investor enthusiasm was stoked by the company's recent participation in a major funding round for humanoid robotics startup Apptronik. This strategic investment underscores a deepening commitment to integrating AI-driven autonomy across its machinery fleet, a move seen as essential for long-term competitiveness and margin expansion. However, the path forward is not without obstacles. Despite the optimism, management flagged significant headwinds, most notably a sharp projected increase in tariff-related costs, which are expected to hit $1.2 billion in fiscal 2026—double the amount from the prior year. Furthermore, the core global large-agriculture industry is still forecast to contract by 15% to 20% this year due to persistently soft commodity prices, indicating that while the bottom may be in, the recovery in Deere's largest segment will likely be gradual.

title: Buc-ee's Blitz: Final Day for Huber Heights Hiring As April Opening Looms
description: HUBER HEIGHTS, Ohio — The beaver is building its dam in Huber Heights, and it needs a massive crew to make it happen. Today, February 19, marks the final day of the Buc-ee's mass hiring event at the Hope Hotel and Conference Center in Dayton, as the Texas-based travel center chain prepares to open its very first Ohio location. The three-day hiring blitz, which kicked off on Tuesday, aims to fill over 200 positions ahead of the store's highly anticipated grand opening. The event runs until 5:00 p.m. today, but eager applicants shouldn't just walk in—interviews are by invitation only for those who have applied online at the company's website. Competitive Pay and Benefits Buc-ee's has built a reputation not just for its immaculate bathrooms and endless walls of jerky, but for its aggressive compensation structure. In an industry where lower wages are often the standard, Buc-ee's is turning heads in the Miami Valley by offering a starting wage between $18 and $23 an hour. Roles like Cashier, Grocery Stocker, Gift Associate, and Janitorial/Maintenance Attendant all start at a solid $18 per hour. For those working in the Deli or Food Service departments—slinging the chain's famous Texas barbecue and Beaver Nuggets—the starting pay bumps up to $21 an hour. Beyond the hourly rate, the company is enticing locals with a robust benefits package that includes full medical, dental, and vision insurance, a 401(k) with a 100% match up to 6%, and three weeks of paid time off that employees can use, cash out, or roll over. A Massive Operation Coming Soon All of this hiring is building toward the official grand opening on Monday, April 6, 2026, at 6:00 a.m. The new travel center, located at 8000 State Route 235 near Interstate 70, will be an absolute behemoth. Spanning 74,000 square feet, the Huber Heights location will feature 120 fueling stations and 700 parking spaces. The excitement is already palpable. Local first responders from Montgomery, Greene, Miami, and Clark counties will even get a special sneak peek of the facility on April 3 before the doors open to the general public. As the hiring event wraps up today, the countdown officially begins. In less than 50 days, the Miami Valley will finally see what the Buc-ee's hype is all about.

title: Meals on Wheels: Dayton Food Truck Rally Unveils Sizzling 2026 Season
description: The Dayton Food Truck Rally has officially released its 2026 season schedule, marking 13 years of the popular outdoor festival series. This year’s lineup features seven major events running from May through September, distributed between two primary downtown venues: The Brightside and Front Street Studios. Each rally is designed as a free, family-friendly gathering that highlights the region's diverse mobile culinary scene. Organizers have confirmed that the 2026 season will continue the tradition of themed festivals, requiring participating vendors to craft specialty menu items that align with specific event topics, such as seafood or tacos. All rallies are rain-or-shine events, utilizing both indoor seating and outdoor beer gardens at the host venues. Historical data shows these gatherings typically attract between 3,000 and 5,000 visitors, making early arrival a consistent recommendation for those looking to avoid the longest queues. The official 2026 schedule includes the following dates: Friday, May 1: ArtEBration Food Truck Rally (Front Street Studios) Friday, May 22: Dayton Burger Fest (The Brightside) Sunday, June 21: Dayton Seafood Fest (The Brightside) Friday, July 10: The Great Dayton Food Truck Rally (Front Street Studios) Friday, July 24: Dayton Mac and Cheese Fest (The Brightside) Friday, Aug. 14: Dayton Taco Fest (The Brightside) Friday, Sept. 4: 61st Anniversary Food Truck Rally (Front Street Studios) For the dates hosted at Front Street Studios, the rallies will coincide with open studio nights, allowing attendees to visit over 100 artist workshops and galleries during the event. This synergy between local art and food remains a cornerstone of the series as it enters its second decade of operation in the Gem City.

title: Rivian Puts Your Car Key on Your Wrist
description:
Rivian owners can finally leave their phones in their pockets. Today, the electric automaker officially launched its native companion app for the Apple Watch, delivering on a long-awaited feature that transforms the wearable into a primary vehicle key and control center. The new app, part of software update 2026.03, provides direct wrist-based access to essential vehicle functions, streamlining the ownership experience for both new and existing models.

At its core, the app is designed for quick, high-frequency interactions. Users can now lock and unlock doors, open front or rear trunks, vent windows, and trigger the alarm with a single tap on their watch. A focus on customization allows drivers to pin up to four of their most-used "Quick Controls" to the app's main screen for immediate access. Furthermore, Rivian has cleverly integrated the Apple Watch's hardware; rotating the Digital Crown provides precise tactile control over cabin temperature and battery charging targets.

Beyond remote controls, the app significantly enhances vehicle entry, though the experience varies by hardware generation. For owners of second-generation Rivian vehicles (2025 and newer), the watch acts as a seamless, passive digital key once set up in Apple Wallet, automatically unlocking the vehicle upon approach. First-generation vehicle owners (2021–2024) also gain a standalone digital key for the first time, but with a slight caveat: the Rivian app must be active in the foreground of the watch screen to unlock the vehicle as you walk up.

The integration extends to the watch face itself, where a new complication displays real-time range and battery percentage at a glance. The app's design mirrors the mobile experience, accurately reflecting the user's specific vehicle configuration and color, and even includes charming details like the animated Gear Guard Yeti. To access these features, customers require a Rivian vehicle running software 2026.03, iOS app version 3.9.0, and an Apple Watch Series 6 or newer.

title: A Win for Accountability: The FDA’s Moderna Reversal and the Shadow of the ‘Moderna Papers’
description: The regulatory halls in Washington D.C. have been the site of a significant tug-of-war this month, and for Dayton residents who have maintained a healthy skepticism of pharmaceutical giants, the latest update is a massive win for public oversight. After a week of standing firm against a potentially flawed application, the FDA has agreed to a conditional review of Moderna’s new mRNA-1010 flu vaccine. While some might see the February 18 reversal as a retreat, a closer look at the strings attached suggests that the days of the ‘blank check’ for mRNA manufacturers are officially over. The standoff began on February 10 when the FDA issued a rare Refusal-to-File letter, effectively calling Moderna’s clinical trials a failure. The agency's primary concern was that Moderna tested its shot for seniors against standard-dose vaccines rather than the high-dose versions that are the proven gold standard for that age group. Following a high-stakes meeting, the FDA will now allow the review to proceed, but only if Moderna accepts a much higher bar: accelerated approval for seniors, which legally mandates follow-up studies to prove the vaccine actually works as well as the current options. This is a dramatic shift from the rapid, emergency-style approvals we saw just a few years ago. For many in the Miami Valley, this friction is a welcome change. The deep-seated skepticism toward Moderna isn’t just about the speed of past rollouts; it is rooted in the perceived lack of transparency during the COVID-19 era. Critics point to the 'Moderna Papers,' a massive trove of documents analyzed by investigative teams led by Naomi Wolf, which allege that the company withheld critical safety data and manipulated clinical outcomes. These allegations have led many prominent health advocates to describe the actions taken during the pandemic as 'crimes against humanity,' citing suppressed evidence of adverse effects and the aggressive enforcement of mandates while essential data remained hidden from the public eye. The tide, however, appears to be turning in favor of the American people. Under the leadership of HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the federal government has already slashed nearly $700 million in mRNA research contracts, signaling a transition toward safer, more traditional vaccine platforms. The current regulatory environment is no longer prioritizing the speed of ‘Warp Speed’ but is instead demanding the level of accountability that Americans have been calling for since 2021. For the families here in Dayton, this means that if this flu shot ever reaches our local clinics, it will have had to survive a gauntlet of scrutiny that Moderna simply wasn't prepared for a year ago. It is a new era of transparency, and for those who value medical freedom and corporate accountability, it is the best news we’ve had in years.

title: Kettering Police Seek Public's Help in Identifying Kroger Theft Suspects
description: By The Dayton Enquirer KETTERING — Local law enforcement is turning to the community for assistance in tracking down two suspects involved in recent thefts at a Kettering grocery store. The Kettering Police Department has released surveillance images and is asking anyone with information to step forward. The incidents occurred at the Kroger location on East Stroop Road over two consecutive days, specifically on February 12 and February 13. While the exact value of the stolen merchandise has not been publicly detailed, police are eager to speak with the individuals pictured in connection with the crimes. According to authorities, the female suspect reportedly fled the scene in a white Chrysler, heading eastbound on East Stroop Road. The department is urging anyone who can identify either suspect, or who might have witnessed the events, to contact them directly at 937-296-2555. As property crimes continue to be a focus for local patrols, community tips often provide the vital link needed to close these cases.

title: Englewood Police Nab 17-Year-Old Suspect Following Multi-Jurisdictional Chase
description: ENGLEWOOD, Ohio — A multi-jurisdictional police chase early Thursday morning culminated in the arrest of a 17-year-old suspect, bringing a swift end to a neighborhood car theft. The incident began around 6:00 a.m. in the Westbrook Meadows subdivision, where Englewood police responded to reports of masked individuals checking for unlocked vehicles. The suspects eventually found an unlocked car with the keys left inside and fled the scene. Officers quickly intercepted the stolen vehicle and successfully deployed a tire-deflation device. Despite having flattened tires, the teen driver led police on a 10-minute pursuit that topped out at just 30 mph before he abandoned the vehicle on Barbarosa Drive. A Collaborative Arrest and Recurring Offenses With crucial assistance from the Montgomery County Sheriff's Office and the Trotwood Police Department, authorities established a perimeter and took the fleeing juvenile into custody without further incident. He was subsequently booked into the Juvenile Intervention Center on felony charges of grand theft of a motor vehicle and failure to comply with a police signal. The arrest highlights an ongoing struggle for local law enforcement dealing with repeat juvenile offenders. According to Englewood police, this is the second time in less than a year that this specific teenager has been arrested for similar crimes. As auto thefts remain a persistent issue across the Miami Valley, officials are once again reminding residents to lock their doors and never leave keys inside unattended vehicles.

title: West Dayton's $10M Facelift: Slower Roads, Bigger Future
description: As a Dayton resident who has watched West Dayton wait for its turn, I can confidently say that change is finally on the horizon. A massive $10 million-plus overhaul of West Third Street and Gettysburg Avenue is moving from the drawing board to the pavement. The City of Dayton, in partnership with the Ohio Department of Transportation (ODOT), is pitching a transformation that aims to turn these historic but historically hazardous corridors into true, pedestrian-friendly main streets. The centerpiece of this plan is a classic road diet for West Third Street. Slated to begin construction in the spring of 2027, the stretch from James H. McGee Boulevard to Abbey Avenue will shrink from five lanes down to three—one in each direction, plus a dedicated center turn lane. But it’s not just about taking space away from cars; it’s about giving it back to the community. We'll see a two-way protected cycle track on the south side, elevated floating bus stops, and raised crosswalks with flashing beacons designed to make multi-modal transit a reality, not just a buzzword. Over on Gettysburg Avenue, the reconstruction focuses heavily on connectivity. Phases 3 and 4, stretching from West Second Street to Gardendale Avenue and kicking off in 2028, will narrow travel lanes from 12 to 11 feet to naturally calm traffic. A new 10-foot-wide shared-use path will extend our city's trail network along the west side of the road, giving cyclists and pedestrians a safe route of their own. Of course, progress comes with a few growing pains. To secure the federal grants funding 75% of this project, the city has to play by federal rules, which means removing traffic signals that no longer meet volume warrants. You can expect signals to vanish at West Third's intersections with Young Avenue, Westown Shopping Center, and Elmhurst Road, plus a few along Gettysburg that will transition to stop signs. So, why this massive overhaul, and why now? It's much bigger than just fresh asphalt. City engineers project that this lane reduction could cut the corridor's staggering crash rate—which has averaged 86 crashes a year—by up to 50%, while only adding about 30 seconds to the average commute. More importantly, this infrastructure sets the stage for a West Dayton renaissance. These safer, sleeker streets will perfectly complement the brand new Dayton Metro Library West Branch and the newly constructed West Patrol Police Station. Furthermore, it paves the way to the historic Wright Company airplane factory site. With ongoing efforts to redevelop those historic hangars into a vibrant museum and community hub, this investment isn't just fixing a road; it's building a gateway to West Dayton's future.

title: The True Cost of the Cloud: Regional Pushback Grows Against Massive Data Center Proposals
description: TRENTON, Ohio — The 'cloud' might seem invisible, but its physical footprint is expanding rapidly right here in Southwest Ohio. A massive wave of proposed data center developments is sweeping through Butler County and the broader Miami Valley, sparking intense pushback from local residents, utility watchdogs, and even state lawmakers who fear the region's power grid and water supplies are being quietly sold off to big tech. Project Mila and the Trenton Megasite The epicenter of this local fight is in Trenton, where California-based real estate giant Prologis recently finalized the purchase of 141 acres of land from the city for approximately $7.7 million. The site, located in the Trenton Industrial Park just east of the Molson Coors facility, is slated for a staggering 1 million-square-foot facility. While city officials champion the estimated 100 to 150 permanent IT and maintenance jobs the center would bring, neighbors remain fiercely skeptical. At recent public meetings, Trenton residents have voiced deep concerns over the facility's immense resource consumption. Data centers require massive amounts of electricity to run servers and millions of gallons of water to cool them. With power demands for these megasites sometimes equaling that of entire small towns, locals fear that existing utility customers will ultimately absorb the costs of grid upgrades and face increased utility rates. Hamilton Hesitates Amid Regional Resistance Just down the road in Hamilton, a similar battle is playing out over a proposed 320,000-square-foot data center on University Boulevard. The developer, Logistix, had requested a staggering 240 megawatts of power for the 29-acre site. However, the city recently paused a feasibility study after determining it would take at least 24 months and immense infrastructure investments just to deliver a fraction of that power. The grassroots resistance in the Miami Valley is now echoing all the way to Columbus. In response to the unchecked boom, Ohio Senate lawmakers recently introduced a slate of bills aimed at reining in data center developments. The proposed legislation would eliminate controversial state sales tax exemptions for data center equipment, cap their daily water consumption, and legally require developers to cover the costs of any new power generation—shielding residential ratepayers from the financial fallout. As artificial intelligence continues to drive unprecedented demand for digital infrastructure, the tug-of-war between lucrative tech investments and the preservation of our local communities is only just beginning.

title: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor Arrested in Historic Misconduct Probe
description: In a move described by legal experts as "unprecedented," Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, the former Duke of York, was arrested by British police on Thursday morning. The arrest marks a significant escalation in the long-running saga surrounding the former royal, shifting focus from previous civil allegations to a criminal investigation into his past official conduct. Detectives from Thames Valley Police arrived at Wood Farm on the Sandringham Estate at approximately 8:00 AM GMT on his 66th birthday. He was taken into custody on suspicion of misconduct in public office. Simultaneous searches were executed at his current residence at Wood Farm and his former home, Royal Lodge in Windsor. Following approximately 11 hours of questioning at Aylsham Police Station, he was released under investigation, meaning he remains a primary suspect while inquiries continue. This event represents the first arrest of a senior member of the Royal Family since the era of King Charles I in 1649. The investigation is distinct from previous civil sexual assault allegations and instead focuses on his tenure as the U.K.'s Special Representative for International Trade and Investment between 2001 and 2011. The arrest follows the January 30, 2026 release of extensive new documents from the U.S. Justice Department's "Epstein files." These newly revealed records provide what investigators term "contemporaneous documentary evidence"—specifically emails and metadata—that allegedly show Mountbatten-Windsor sharing confidential state information with Jeffrey Epstein. Among the most serious allegations is the sharing of a 2010 "confidential brief" regarding investment opportunities in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, at a time when British forces were actively deployed in combat operations there. Other newly discovered emails suggest he forwarded sensitive visit reports from official trade missions in Vietnam, Singapore, and Hong Kong to Epstein just minutes after receiving them from his government advisers. The constitutional and political reaction has been swift and severe, signaling a definitive break between the Crown and the former prince. Buckingham Palace, having already confirmed he was stripped of his final honorary titles in October 2025 and evicted from Royal Lodge earlier this year, issued a statement from King Charles III saying only that "the law must take its course." Prime Minister Keir Starmer reiterated that "everybody is equal under the law." Misconduct in public office is a serious common law offense in the U.K. that carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment.

title: Wilberforce Pioneers New Era with Women's Flag Football
description: WILBERFORCE, Ohio — In a historic move for both the institution and the region, Wilberforce University officially announced the launch of women's flag football as an intercollegiate sport on Wednesday. As the nation's oldest private HBCU, Wilberforce is positioning itself at the forefront of a rapidly expanding athletic movement, with competition slated to begin in the Spring of 2027. "This is an exciting moment in Wilberforce's athletic history, expanding opportunities, elevating women's sports, and advancing our commitment to bold leadership and empowerment," said Wilberforce President Dr. Vann R. Newkirk during the February 18 announcement. The university has tapped Earnest Wilson III to lead the inaugural program. Wilson, who currently serves as the university's Director of Football Operations, brings over 35 years of collegiate and professional football experience. He will immediately begin building the foundation of the team, with plans to recruit an initial class of 25 to 30 student-athletes. The recruitment effort is expected to capitalize on the explosive growth of the sport locally; Ohio recently became the 17th state to sanction high school girls' flag football, and more than 80 high schools across the state now offer the sport. The introduction of women's flag football serves as a catalyst for much broader athletic ambitions at Wilberforce. Dr. Newkirk described the new program as the first element in a sweeping effort to revive the university's football legacy. Wilberforce has not fielded a men's football team since 1947, but university officials are actively fundraising to construct a new 4,000-seat stadium adjacent to the existing gymnasium. If successful, this facility will serve as the home for the women's flag football team and potentially a resurrected men's intercollegiate football team by late 2027 or 2028. Wilberforce's entry into women's flag football aligns perfectly with the sport's rising global profile. Gaining rapid traction in the NAIA—where Wilberforce competes—flag football is also set to make its Olympic debut at the 2028 Los Angeles Games. The Bulldogs will join a growing regional competitive landscape that includes nearby Wittenberg University, setting the stage for exciting local rivalries in the years to come.

title: Dragons Gear Up for 2026: Entertainment Auditions and a New Era in the Dugout
description: As the Dayton Dragons prepare to celebrate their 26th season of baseball in the Miami Valley, the organization is calling on local talent to help bring Day Air Ballpark to life. With Opening Day rapidly approaching on April 7, the front office is actively finalizing the roster for its fan-favorite entertainment crews, extending a key musical deadline, and preparing to welcome a familiar face as the team's new manager. The search is currently underway to fill out the 2026 entertainment staff, which includes mascot performers, the energetic Green Team, and dynamic on-field hosts. For those aspiring to don the suits of Heater, Gem, or Blaze, the team is looking for performers between 5'4" and 6'2". While athletic or dance experience is a plus, a high-energy personality is the primary requirement. Meanwhile, the Green Team serves as the backbone of the stadium's atmosphere, tasked with facilitating in-game skits, shooting t-shirts into the sold-out crowds, and dancing on the dugouts. On-field hosts act as the nightly emcees, requiring quick wit and undeniable charisma. All applicants must be at least 16 years old by January 1, 2026, and available to work nights and weekends throughout the 66-game home schedule. For local vocalists, there is still time to secure a spot behind the microphone. The Dragons recently extended the deadline for their virtual National Anthem tryouts to Sunday, March 8. Singers and musicians are asked to submit high-quality, landscape-oriented videos through the team's website. Finalists will be selected to perform throughout the summer, with one grand prize winner earning the prestigious opportunity to perform in front of a packed house on Opening Day against the Lake County Captains. The fresh faces in the entertainment crew will be matched by a new leadership presence in the home dugout. The Cincinnati Reds recently announced that Julio Morillo will serve as the 13th manager in Dragons franchise history. Morillo's appointment represents a full-circle moment for the 33-year-old, who suited up as a catcher for the Dragons in 2014 and 2015. After concluding his playing career, Morillo transitioned into the Reds' front office, serving as a Spanish language translator and baseball operations assistant before managing in the minors and the prestigious Arizona Fall League. He replaces Vince Harrison Jr. and will be joined by returning pitching coach Willie Blair and hitting coach Troy Gingrich to guide the next wave of Reds prospects. With auditions wrapping up and the coaching staff locked in, the countdown to another vibrant summer of baseball in downtown Dayton is officially on.

title: Meta Slashes Employee Stock Awards by 5% to Fuel AI Ambitions
description: Meta Platforms is officially tightening its belt on employee compensation, cutting annual stock awards by 5% for the majority of its workforce. This move, while seemingly modest on an individual level, represents a massive reallocation of capital as CEO Mark Zuckerberg aggressively pivots the social media giant toward an artificial intelligence-first future. The Great Reallocation: People to Processors Stock awards have historically been the golden handcuffs of Silicon Valley, often making up the lion's share of a tech worker's total compensation. By trimming these equity grants, Meta is effectively shifting its operational expenses from human capital to computational power. The company is staring down a staggering Capital Expenditure (CapEx) budget for 2026, largely dedicated to acquiring specialized AI chips and constructing the power-hungry data centers required to train and run next-generation models. A Pattern of Compensation Tightening This latest 5% reduction in stock awards is part of a broader, multi-year strategy to streamline operations. It follows initiatives from 2025 where Meta shrunk the value of equity refreshers by roughly 10% and executed a 5% workforce reduction targeting lower performers. Furthermore, the company kicked off 2026 by eliminating over 1,000 roles in its Reality Labs division, deliberately pivoting resources away from its early metaverse ambitions and pouring them directly into AI wearables and foundational infrastructure. Interestingly, these austerity measures do not apply evenly across the corporate ladder. While rank-and-file employees see their equity shrink, Meta's board recently approved an increase in the cash bonus ceiling for top executives, raising the maximum payout from 75% to 200% of their base salary. This stark divergence highlights a targeted strategy to heavily incentivize the top leadership tasked with steering this high-stakes AI transition. The New AI-First Performance Culture Beyond compensation, Meta is radically altering its internal expectations. The company is actively integrating 'AI-driven impact' into employee reviews across all departments, not just engineering. Staff are now expected to consistently demonstrate how they are leveraging generative AI tools to accelerate workflows, write code, or improve project outcomes. It is a clear mandate from leadership: adapt to the AI-augmented workflow or risk being left behind. The High-Stakes Bet Unlike its chief rivals, Microsoft and Google, Meta does not operate a massive enterprise cloud business to offset the costs of its AI investments by renting compute power to others. Instead, Meta must prove to Wall Street that these multi-billion-dollar infrastructure bets will directly translate into superior ad targeting, higher user engagement across its app family, and a dominant position in the next era of consumer technology. As the tech sector continues to mature, Meta's aggressive financial maneuvering serves as a clear bellwether. The era of unchecked employee perks is fading, replaced by a hyper-competitive, efficiency-obsessed culture squarely focused on winning the artificial intelligence arms race.

title: Trump: 10 Days for an Iran Deal, or "Bad Things Will Happen"
description: WASHINGTON – President Donald Trump used the inaugural convening of his newly formed Board of Peace on Thursday to deliver a stark ultimatum regarding the standoff with Iran, blending the administration's stated pursuit of global stability with a severe threat of force. While the new advisory body is tasked with developing frameworks for conflict resolution, the President’s keynote address highlighted the administration’s reliance on hard-nosed, coercive diplomacy. Trump declared that the United States would determine within a tight window—initially stated as "probably 10 days," and later clarified by officials as a maximum of two weeks—whether a "meaningful deal" to curb Tehran's nuclear ambitions is achievable. If this final diplomatic push fails, the President warned, "bad things will happen," a clear allusion to potential military action. This specific timeline is not arbitrary; it directly correlates with commitments made during indirect negotiations in Geneva earlier this week. On Tuesday, Iranian negotiators, communicating through Omani intermediaries, agreed to provide a formal written response to U.S. demands within roughly two weeks. President Trump has effectively transformed that administrative deadline into a strategic ultimatum. This development underscores a profound disconnect between public diplomatic statements and the tense reality on the ground. While Iranian state media characterized the Geneva sessions as having made "good progress based on guiding principles," the White House remains deeply skeptical. Administration sources indicate that "significant gaps" persist, primarily concerning Iran’s refusal to abandon uranium enrichment entirely and its continued ballistic missile development. To bridge these gaps, the Trump administration is leveraging an unprecedented projection of military power, executing the most significant U.S. buildup in the Persian Gulf region since 2003. This dual-track strategy of high-stakes diplomacy backed by overwhelming force is visible in real-time. The USS Abraham Lincoln carrier strike group is already on station in the Arabian Sea, providing immediate strike capabilities. Furthermore, the Navy has confirmed that the USS Gerald R. Ford, the world’s largest and most advanced warship, is currently transiting toward the theater to augment the U.S. presence. These massive naval assets are supported by squadrons of F-22 stealth fighters and other combat aircraft recently moved to forward bases in the Gulf. The administration’s insistence on "peace through strength" is rooted in the volatile events of the past year. Following the 12-day conflict in June 2025, during which U.S. and Israeli forces conducted surgical strikes against Iranian nuclear infrastructure, Washington has hardened its position to a "zero enrichment" policy to prevent the regime from rebuilding its capabilities. Coupled with recent, deadly internal unrest that has shaken the clerical regime's domestic stability, the White House calculates that this ticking clock, combined with visible firepower, offers the only viable path to a definitive resolution. However, as the 10-day countdown begins, the risk of miscalculation by either side remains acute.

title: Artemis II: NASA High-Stakes Fueling Test Underway to Secure March Launch
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — NASA is currently executing a high-stakes, second "wet dress rehearsal" for the Artemis II mission, a critical fueling test that will determine when the first crewed flight to the moon in over 50 years can finally get off the ground. As of Thursday, the countdown clock at Launch Pad 39B is ticking toward a simulated launch time of 8:30 p.m. EST. The massive Space Launch System (SLS) rocket is in its tanking phase, a highly complex process of loading more than 700,000 gallons of super-cold liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen into the rocket’s core and upper stages. Launch controllers are meticulously running through terminal countdown procedures, simulating the exact conditions, holds, and recycles they will face on launch day. Operators are tasked with conducting two separate runs of the final ten minutes of the countdown. The sequence involves pausing at T-minus 1 minute and 30 seconds, resuming, and pausing again at T-minus 33 seconds. Following this, the clock will recycle back to T-minus 10 minutes for a second simulated run. This rigorous process tests the team's ability to handle technical or weather-related launch scrub scenarios in real-time. Overcoming Hydrogen Leaks and Hardware Hurdles This second rehearsal was mandated after a series of frustrating but necessary delays. The initial wet dress rehearsal on February 3 was terminated at T-minus 5 minutes and 15 seconds due to a liquid hydrogen leak at an umbilical interface. A subsequent partial fueling test on February 12 uncovered a separate issue: a clogged filter in the ground support equipment that was restricting the flow of liquid hydrogen into the core stage. Engineers successfully replaced the faulty filter over the weekend, clearing the way for today's full-scale simulation. While the four-person Artemis II crew—NASA astronauts Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, Christina Koch, and Canadian Space Agency astronaut Jeremy Hansen—are not aboard the Orion capsule for this test, ground teams are treating the pad as if they are. A specialized "closeout crew" was dispatched to practice the exact procedures for securing the astronauts and sealing the Orion spacecraft’s hatch, ensuring the environment is perfectly safe for human occupants. Looking Ahead to a March Launch Artemis II is slated to send its crew on a 10-day lunar flyby, testing Orion's deep-space life support and navigation systems ahead of the Artemis III lunar landing. If today's tanking and terminal countdown operations conclude successfully, NASA will clear the final major ground hurdle and set an official launch date. Agency managers have identified March 6, 2026, as the earliest possible launch window, which allows sufficient time for post-test data review and the transition to actual launch operations. NASA leadership will hold a press conference tomorrow, February 20, at 11:00 a.m. ET to share the official results of the wet dress rehearsal and outline the final path to the launchpad.

title: Betrayal in Tipp City: Husband Charged in Murder of Ashley Flynn
description: TIPP CITY, Ohio — In a development that has sent shockwaves through the Miami Valley, Caleb Carl Flynn, 39, was arrested Thursday evening and charged with the murder of his wife, Ashley Flynn. Initially reported as a tragic home invasion on Monday morning, the investigation took a sharp turn as Tipp City detectives, working alongside the FBI and Ohio BCI, uncovered evidence that contradicted Caleb Flynn’s initial account. Flynn had told dispatchers that an intruder broke into their Cunningham Court home around 2:30 a.m., prompting him to hide in a bedroom with his juvenile daughter while his wife was fatally shot twice. Caleb Flynn now faces a heavy slate of charges, including one count of homicide, two counts of felonious assault, and two counts of tampering with evidence. The tampering charges suggest that investigators believe the crime scene may have been staged to support the home invasion narrative. Caleb Flynn, a former music pastor and one-time contestant on 'American Idol,' is currently being held at the Miami County Jail. The couple was well-known in the community; Ashley was a beloved 7th-grade volleyball coach and teacher. A community fundraiser for the family had gathered over $80,000 in donations prior to the arrest. Police Chief Greg Adkins credited the 'tireless, around-the-clock' work of investigators for the breakthrough. While a suspect is in custody, officials stressed that the investigation is far from over as they continue to process forensic evidence from the home.

title: Amazon's Liability Shock: When Algorithms Cross the Line
description: OLYMPIA, Wash. — The Washington State Supreme Court delivered a unanimous ruling on February 19, 2026, that will undoubtedly send ripples through the e-commerce sector. The court decided that families of individuals who tragically took their own lives using highly concentrated sodium nitrite purchased on Amazon can proceed to trial, reversing a lower court's dismissal. At first glance, this ruling might trigger alarms for those who champion free markets and individual responsibility. Traditionally, the law provides a robust "misuse defense": a retailer cannot be held liable if a consumer intentionally uses a legal product to harm themselves. Holding a platform accountable for the tragic choices of its users threatens to set a slippery precedent. However, the justices didn't discard personal responsibility; rather, they focused heavily on the unique intersection of product purity and algorithmic behavior. The chemical at the center of the dispute, sodium nitrite, is entirely legal and commonly used at very low concentrations (around 6%) to cure meats. The controversy stems from the specific product sold: reagent-grade sodium nitrite at 98% to 99.6% purity. At this concentration, the chemical has virtually no legitimate household use and is highly lethal. What transforms this from a standard product liability case into a landmark tech-accountability issue is the role of Amazon's proprietary algorithms. The plaintiffs allege that Amazon's "Frequently Bought Together" feature actively bundled the deadly chemical with anti-emetic drugs (to prevent the body's natural urge to vomit) and a well-known suicide instruction manual. To the court, this crossed the line from operating a passive, neutral marketplace into actively assembling a lethal toolkit for vulnerable buyers. Furthermore, the lawsuit claims Amazon was repeatedly warned by parents and regulators starting in 2018 about the fatal misuse of the product, yet the company allegedly removed one-star reviews warning of the danger while keeping the product listings active. The court found that when a retailer has explicit, repeated knowledge that a highly lethal product with no household utility is being used almost exclusively for self-harm, a legal "duty of care" emerges to prevent foreseeable tragedies. This legal shift mirrors recent legislative actions. Last year, Washington lawmakers passed "Tyler's Law" with overwhelming bipartisan support, restricting the sale of sodium nitrite in concentrations over 10% to verified businesses and laboratories. This bipartisan consensus underscores that regulating industrial-grade poisons sold to residential addresses is increasingly viewed not as government overreach, but as a necessary guardrail for public safety. For investors and e-commerce giants, the message is clear: the shield of the "neutral platform" is cracking. When algorithms actively bundle dangerous products and corporate infrastructure ignores direct warnings of localized harm, the courts—and the market—will demand accountability. Amazon has since voluntarily restricted high-concentration sodium nitrite sales to verified business accounts, a quiet acknowledgment that the era of blind algorithmic retail may be coming to an end.

title: Feds and Local Police Dismantle Major Dayton Fentanyl Pipelines
description: The Dayton area has seen a massive surge in successful drug enforcement operations this February, resulting in the seizure of hundreds of pounds of narcotics and the arrest of several key traffickers. Two primary investigations—one federal and one local—have effectively disrupted the flow of fentanyl and methamphetamine into the Miami Valley. The Multi-State Freight Shipment Bust In early February, a joint operation led by the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) intercepted a massive freight package at a Dayton distribution center. Federal agents discovered approximately 262 pounds of a cocaine and fentanyl mixture, alongside 170 pounds of methamphetamine and 80 pounds of marijuana. To identify the recipients, agents conducted a 'controlled delivery' on February 3. They monitored as 40-year-old Jason Heath of Dayton and 33-year-old Mark Lane of Cincinnati arrived in a white Mercedes van to retrieve the pallets. Two additional suspects from Los Angeles, Roderic Searcy (60) and Craig Worthen (40), followed them in a separate vehicle to a Dayton residence. Once the suspects realized the drugs had been removed from the packaging by law enforcement, they attempted to flee but were quickly apprehended. All four men now face federal conspiracy charges with a mandatory minimum of 10 years to life in prison. Richmond Avenue Raid Just days later, on February 5, Dayton Police detectives executed a high-impact search warrant in the 300 block of Richmond Avenue. This local operation targeted a high-volume distribution hub, resulting in the recovery of over 1.3 kilograms of fentanyl and approximately 10,000 pressed fentanyl pills. Detectives also seized 134.8 grams of crack cocaine, six firearms, and $138,751 in cash. Keith Devon Jones, 34, was arrested at the scene and faces multiple felony charges for trafficking and possession. Ongoing Regional Enforcement These major seizures were followed by a 'Violent Crime Reduction Operation' on February 12. Dayton Police, in coordination with the Ohio State Highway Patrol, targeted the Gettysburg Avenue area, leading to nine additional felony arrests and the recovery of more illegal narcotics and firearms. Authorities emphasize that these back-to-back operations are part of an intensified strategy to combat the regional overdose crisis by cutting off the supply at its highest levels.
